column2: '15Oct'
column3: 1)	" Well
column4: let -- let me say
column5: Bob
column6: thank you. And thanks to Hofstra.  And
column7: by the way
column8: our beloved Nancy Reagan is in the hospital tonight
column9: so our thoughts and prayers are going with you.  It's good to see you again
column10: Senator Obama.  Americans are hurting right now
column11: and they're angry. They're hurting
column12: and they're angry. They're innocent victims of greed and excess on Wall Street and as well as Washington
column13: D.C. And they're angry
column14: and they have every reason to be angry.  And they want this country to go in a new direction. And there are elements of my proposal that you just outlined which I won't repeat.  But we also have to have a short-term fix
column16: and long- term fixes.  Let me just talk to you about one of the short-term fixes.  The catalyst for this housing crisis was the Fannie and Freddie Mae that caused subprime lending situation that now caused the housing market in America to collapse.  I am convinced that
column17: until we reverse this continued decline in home ownership and put a floor under it
column18: and so that people have not only the hope and belief they can stay in their homes and realize the American dream
column19: but that value will come up.  Now
column20: we have allocated $750 billion. Let's take 300 of that billion and go in and buy those home loan mortgages and negotiate with those people in their homes
column22: so that they can afford to pay the mortgage
column23: stay in their home.  Now
column24: I know the criticism of this.

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

column1: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber
column2: his name is Joe Wurzelbacher. Joe wants to buy the business that he has been in for all of these years
column3: worked 10
column4: 12 hours a day. And he wanted to buy the business but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes.  You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket which was going to increase his taxes
column5: which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people
column6: which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.  Now Senator Obama talks about the very
column7: very rich. Joe
column8: I want to tell you
column9: I'll not only help you buy that business that you worked your whole life for and be able -- and I'll keep your taxes low and I'll provide available and affordable health care for you and your employees.  And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column1: He has been watching ads of Senator McCain's. Let me tell you what I'm actually going to do. I think tax policy is a major difference between Senator McCain and myself. And we both want to cut taxes
column2: the difference is who we want to cut taxes for. Now
column3: Senator McCain
column4: the centerpiece of his economic proposal is to provide $200 billion in additional tax breaks to some of the wealthiest corporations in America. Exxon Mobil
column5: and other oil companies
column6: for example
column7: would get an additional $4 billion in tax breaks.  What I've said is I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of working Americans
column8: 95 percent. If you make more -- if you make less than a quarter million dollars a year
column9: then you will not see your income tax go up
column10: your capital gains tax go up
column11: your payroll tax. Not one dime. And 95 percent of working families
column12: 95 percent of you out there
column13: will get a tax cut. In fact
column14: independent studies have looked at our respective plans and have concluded that I provide three times the amount of tax relief to middle-class families than Senator McCain does.

column2: the conversation I had with Joe the plumber
column3: what I essentially said to him was
column4: ""Five years ago
column5: when you were in a position to buy your business
column6: you needed a tax cut then."" And what I want to do is to make sure that the plumber
column7: the nurse
column8: the firefighter
column9: the teacher
column10: the young entrepreneur who doesn't yet have money
column11: I want to give them a tax break now. And that requires us to make some important choices.  The last point I'll make about small businesses. Not only do 98 percent of small businesses make less than $250
column13: but I also want to give them additional tax breaks
column14: because they are the drivers of the economy. They produce the most jobs.

column2: when Senator Obama ended up his conversation with Joe the plumber -- we need to spread the wealth around. In other words
column3: we're going to take Joe's money
column4: give it to Senator Obama
column5: and let him spread the wealth around. I want Joe the plumber to spread that wealth around. You told him you wanted to spread the wealth around.  The whole premise behind Senator Obama's plans are class warfare
column6: let's spread the wealth around. I want small businesses -- and by the way
column7: the small businesses that we're talking about would receive an increase in their taxes right now.  Who -- why would you want to increase anybody's taxes right now? Why would you want to do that
column8: anyone
column9: anyone in America
column10: when we have such a tough time
column11: when these small business people
column12: like Joe the plumber
column13: are going to create jobs
column14: unless you take that money from him and spread the wealth around.  I'm not going to...

column1: We're not going to do that in my administration.
If I can answer the question. Number one
column2: I want to cut taxes for 95 percent of Americans. Now
column3: it is true that my friend and supporter
column4: Warren Buffett
column5: for example
column6: could afford to pay a little more in taxes in order...

column1: We're talking about Joe the plumber.
... in order to give -- in order to give additional tax cuts to Joe the plumber before he was at the point where he could make $250
column2: 000. Then Exxon Mobil
column3: which made $12 billion
column4: record profits
column5: over the last several quarters
column6: they can afford to pay a little more so that ordinary families who are hurting out there -- they're trying to figure out how they're going to afford food
column7: how they're going to save for their kids' college education
column8: they need a break.  So
column9: look
column10: nobody likes taxes. I would prefer that none of us had to pay taxes
column11: including myself. But ultimately
column12: we've got to pay for the core investments that make this economy strong and somebody's got to do it.

column1: Nobody likes taxes. Let's not raise anybody's taxes. OK?

column2: I don't mind paying a little more.

column1: The fact is that businesses in America today are paying the second highest tax rate of anywhere in the world. Our tax rate for business in America is 35 percent. Ireland
column2: it's 11 percent. Where are companies going to go where they can create jobs and where they can do best in business?  We need to cut the business tax rate in America. We need to encourage business.  Now
column3: of all times in America
column4: we need to cut people's taxes. We need to encourage business
column5: create jobs
column6: not spread the wealth around.

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

column1: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber

column8: I want to tell you
column9: I'll not only help you buy that business that you worked your whole life for and be able -- and I'll keep your taxes low and I'll provide available and affordable health care for you and your employees.  And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

column1: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber

column6: which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.  Now Senator Obama talks about the very

column8: I want to tell you
column9: I'll not only help you buy that business that you worked your whole life for and be able -- and I'll keep your taxes low and I'll provide available and affordable health care for you and your employees.  And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column1: He has been watching ads of Senator McCain's. Let me tell you what I'm actually going to do. I think tax policy is a major difference between Senator McCain and myself. And we both want to cut taxes

column9: then you will not see your income tax go up
column10: your capital gains tax go up
column11: your payroll tax. Not one dime. And 95 percent of working families

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column10: Senator Obama.  Americans are hurting right now
column11: and they're angry. They're hurting
column12: and they're angry. They're innocent victims of greed and excess on Wall Street and as well as Washington
column13: D.C. And they're angry
column14: and they have every reason to be angry.  And they want this country to go in a new direction. And there are elements of my proposal that you just outlined which I won't repeat.  But we also have to have a short-term fix
column16: and long- term fixes.  Let me just talk to you about one of the short-term fixes.  The catalyst for this housing crisis was the Fannie and Freddie Mae that caused subprime lending situation that now caused the housing market in America to collapse.  I am convinced that

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

column1: No. I would like to mention that a couple days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber

column6: which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.  Now Senator Obama talks about the very

And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column2: what about the citizen that stayed in their homes? That paid their mortgage payments? It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned. And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And so we've got to reverse this. We ought to put the homeowners first. And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
first of all
column3: I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again
column4: and thank you
column5: Bob. I think everybody understands at this point that we are experiencing the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression. And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step. And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up. Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.  And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out. But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class. Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis. So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.  Number one
column6: let's focus on jobs. I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.  Number two
column7: let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200
column9: and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.  Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners. That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.  I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it
column10: because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan
column11: it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less. And we don't want to waste taxpayer money. And we've got to get the financial package working much quicker than it has been working.  Last point I want to make
column12: though. We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with. We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away. We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.

And I will not have -- I will not stand for a tax increase on small business income. Fifty percent of small business income taxes are paid by small businesses. That's 16 million jobs in America. And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package
column6: if it's structured properly
column7: and
column8: as president
column9: I will make sure it's structured properly
column10: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column11: and that's important to understand. But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.  Now
column12: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package
column6: if it's structured properly
column7: and
column8: as president
column9: I will make sure it's structured properly
column10: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column11: and that's important to understand. But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.  Now
column12: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.
