column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package
column6: if it's structured properly
column7: and
column8: as president
column9: I will make sure it's structured properly
column10: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column11: and that's important to understand. But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.  Now
column12: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package

column8: as president
column9: I will make sure it's structured properly
column10: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column11: and that's important to understand. But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.  Now
column12: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column3: 2)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I think it's important for the American public to understand that the $750 billion rescue package
column6: if it's structured properly
column7: and
column8: as president
column9: I will make sure it's structured properly
column10: means that ultimately taxpayers get their money back
column11: and that's important to understand. But there is no doubt that we've been living beyond our means and we're going to have to make some adjustments.  Now
column12: what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut. I haven't made a promise about...

column1: Absolutely. So let me get to that. What I want to emphasize
column2: though
column3: is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go. Every dollar that I've proposed
column4: I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.

column2: just to give you an example
column3: we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies. It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better. It's not improving our health care system. It's just a giveaway. We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work. And I want to go through the federal budget line by line
column4: page by page
column5: programs that don't work
column6: we should cut. Programs that we need
column7: we should make them work better.  Now
column8: what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people. I mentioned health care earlier.  If we make investments now so that people have coverage
column9: that we are preventing diseases
column10: that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.  If we invest in a serious energy policy
column11: that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.  If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college
column12: that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.  But what is absolutely true is that
column13: once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump
column14: that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.  And we're going to have to embrace a culture and an ethic of responsibility
column16: corporations
column17: the federal government
column18: and individuals out there who may be living beyond their means.

column2: thank you
column3: Bob. I just want to get back to this home ownership. During the Depression era
column4: we had a thing called the home ownership loan corporation. And they went out and bought up these mortgages. And people were able to stay in their homes
column5: and eventually the values of those homes went up
column6: and they actually made money. And
column7: by the way
column8: this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.  So
column9: obviously
column10: if we can start increasing home values
column11: then there will be creation of wealth.

column2: first -- second of all
column3: energy independence. We have to have nuclear power. We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much. It's wind
column4: tide
column5: solar
column6: natural gas
column7: nuclear
column8: off-shore drilling
column9: which Senator Obama has opposed. And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.  OK
column10: what -- what would I cut? I would have
column11: first of all
column12: across-the-board spending freeze
column13: OK? Some people say that's a hatchet. That's a hatchet
column14: and then I would get out a scalpel
column15: OK?  Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country. We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.  Government spending has gone completely out of control; $10 trillion dollar debt we're giving to our kids
column16: a half-a-trillion dollars we owe China.  I know how to save billions of dollars in defense spending. I know how to eliminate programs.

column2: one of them would be the marketing assistance program. Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol. I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.  I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.  I know how to save billions. I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years
column3: as you might recall
column4: that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer
column5: DOD
column6: and people ended up in jail.  But I would fight for a line-item veto
column7: and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill. Senator Obama has asked for nearly $1 billion in pork-barrel earmark projects...

column1: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown. That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.

column2: look
column3: I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze. It sounds good. It's proposed periodically. It doesn't happen. And
column4: in fact
column5: an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet
column6: and we do need a scalpel
column7: because there are some programs that don't work at all. There are some programs that are underfunded. And I want to make sure that we are focused on those programs that work.  Now
column8: Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks. That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.  Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget. There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on
column9: and they need to be eliminated. But it's not going to solve the problem.  Now
column10: the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history
column11: just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.  When President Bush came into office
column12: we had a budget surplus and the national debt was a little over $5 trillion. It has doubled over the last eight years.

column1: And we are now looking at a deficit of well over half a trillion dollars. So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit. And
column2: frankly
column3: Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.  We've got to take this in a new direction
column4: that's what I propose as president.

column1: Sure I do. And let me tell you...

column2: I am not President Bush. If you wanted to run against President Bush
column3: you should have run four years ago. I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country. Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets. He voted twice for a budget resolution that increases the taxes on individuals making $42
column4: 000 a year. Of course
column5: we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget. It's completely out of control.  The mayor of New York
column6: Mayor Bloomberg
column7: just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City. They're doing it all over America because they have to. Because they have to balance their budgets. I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...

column1: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence. Now
column2: look
column3: Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that
column4: and they want a new direction. I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.  Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for. He voted for the last two budgets that had that $24 billion more in spending than the budget that the Bush administration proposed. He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed. So the fact is
column5: let's look at our records
column6: Senator Obama. Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.  I have fought against spending. I have fought against special interests. I have fought for reform. You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.

column2: there's a lot of stuff that was put out there
column3: so let me try to address it. First of all
column4: in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party
column5: the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform
column6: which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers
column7: a major constituency in the Democratic Party. I support...

column1: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers. Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union. I support clean coal technology. Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists. So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle. Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said
column2: the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42
column3: 000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.  Even FOX News disputes it
column4: and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me. So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies
column5: it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people
column6: on tax policy
column7: on energy policy
column8: on spending priorities
column9: you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.  Now
column10: you've shown independence -- commendable independence
column11: on some key issues like torture
column12: for example
column13: and I give you enormous credit for that. But when it comes to economic policies
column14: essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing. And it hasn't worked.  And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked. We need to move in a new direction.

column2: Bob.

column1: OK. But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration. I have disagreed with leaders of my own party. I've got the scars to prove it. Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time. Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks
column2: whether it be the issue of torture
column3: whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq
column4: which I vigorously opposed. Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs
column5: importation. Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights. Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.  I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.

column2: your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.

column3: 3)	" Well
column4: this has been a tough campaign. It's been a very tough campaign. And I know from my experience in many campaigns that
column5: if Senator Obama had asked -- responded to my urgent request to sit down
column6: and do town hall meetings
column7: and come before the American people
column8: we could have done at least 10 of them by now. When Senator Obama was first asked
column9: he said
column10: ""Any place
column11: any time
column12: the way Barry Goldwater and Jack Kennedy agreed to do
column13: before the intervention of the tragedy at Dallas. So I think the tone of this campaign could have been very different.  And the fact is
column14: it's gotten pretty tough. And I regret some of the negative aspects of both campaigns. But the fact is that it has taken many turns which I think are unacceptable.  One of them happened just the other day
column15: when a man I admire and respect -- I've written about him -- Congressman John Lewis
column16: an American hero
column17: made allegations that Sarah Palin and I were somehow associated with the worst chapter in American history
column18: segregation
column19: deaths of children in church bombings
column20: George Wallace. That
column22: was so hurtful.  And
column23: Senator Obama
column24: you didn't repudiate those remarks. Every time there's been an out-of-bounds remark made by a Republican
column25: no matter where they are
column26: I have repudiated them. I hope that Senator Obama will repudiate those remarks that were made by Congressman John Lewis
column27: very unfair and totally inappropriate.  So I want to tell you
column28: we will run a truthful campaign. This is a tough campaign. And it's a matter of fact that Senator Obama has spent more money on negative ads than any political campaign in history. And I can prove it. And
column29: Senator Obama
column30: when he said -- and he signed a piece of paper that said he would take public financing for his campaign if I did -- that was back when he was a long-shot candidate -- you didn't keep your word.  And when you looked into the camera in a debate with Senator Clinton and said
column31: ""I will sit down and negotiate with John McCain about public financing before I make a decision
column32: you didn't tell the American people the truth because you didn't.  And that's -- that's -- that's an unfortunate part. Now we have the highest spending by Senator Obama's campaign than any time since Watergate.

column2: look
column3: you know
column4: I think that we expect presidential campaigns to be tough. I think that
column5: if you look at the record and the impressions of the American people -- Bob
column6: your network just did a poll
column7: showing that two-thirds of the American people think that Senator McCain is running a negative campaign versus one-third of mine. And 100 percent
column8: John
column9: of your ads -- 100 percent of them have been negative.

column2: now
column3: I think the American people are less interested in our hurt feelings during the course of the campaign than addressing the issues that matter to them so deeply. And there is nothing wrong with us having a vigorous debate like we're having tonight about health care
column4: about energy policy
column5: about tax policy. That's the stuff that campaigns should be made of.  The notion
column6: though
column7: that because we're not doing town hall meetings that justifies some of the ads that have been going up
column8: not just from your own campaign directly
column9: John
column10: but 527s and other organizations that make some pretty tough accusations
column11: well
column12: I don't mind being attacked for the next three weeks.  What the American people can't afford
column13: though
column14: is four more years of failed economic policies. And what they deserve over the next four weeks is that we talk about what's most pressing to them: the economic crisis.  Senator McCain's own campaign said publicly last week that
column15: if we keep on talking about the economic crisis
column16: we lose
column17: so we need to change the subject.  And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy
column18: devoted to talking about health care
column19: devoted to talking about energy
column20: and figuring out how the American people can send their kids to college. And that is something that I would welcome. But it requires
column22: a recognition that politics as usual
column23: as been practiced over the last several years
column24: is not solving the big problems here in America.

column2: if you'll turn on the television

column1: Every other ad -- ever other ad was an attack ad on my health care plan. And any objective observer has said it's not true. You're running ads right now that say that I oppose federal funding for stem cell research. I don't. You're running ads that misportray completely my position on immigration. So the fact is that Senator Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics
column2: going back to the beginning
column3: amounts of money in negative attack ads on me.  And of course
column4: I've been talking about the economy. Of course
column5: I've talked to people like Joe the plumber and tell him that I'm not going to spread his wealth around. I'm going to let him keep his wealth. And of course
column6: we're talking about positive plan of action to restore this economy and restore jobs in America.  That's what my campaign is all about and that's what it'll continue to be all about.  But again
column7: I did not hear a repudiation of Congressman...

column3: if we want to talk about Congressman Lewis
column4: who is an American hero
column5: he
column6: unprompted by my campaign

column8: made a statement that he was troubled with what he was hearing at some of the rallies that your running mate was holding
column9: in which all the Republican reports indicated were shouting

column11: things like ""terrorist"" and ""kill him

column13: didn't stop

column15: that's kind of out of line."" And I think Congressman Lewis' point was that we have to be careful about how we deal with our supporters.  Now...

... my response. I do think that he inappropriately drew a comparison between what was happening there and what had happened during the civil rights movement

column10: and that's what I have been trying to focus on this entire campaign.

column1: Let me just say categorically I'm proud of the people that come to our rallies. Whenever you get a large rally of 10
column6: 000 people
column7: you're going to have some fringe peoples. You know that. And I've -- and we've always said that that's not appropriate. But to somehow say that group of young women who said ""Military wives for McCain"" are somehow saying anything derogatory about you
column8: but anything -- and those veterans that wear those hats that say ""World War II
column9: Vietnam
column10: Korea
column11: Iraq
column12: I'm not going to stand for people saying that the people that come to my rallies are anything but the most dedicated
column13: patriotic men and women that are in this nation and they're great citizens.  And I'm not going to stand for somebody saying that because someone yelled something at a rally -- there's a lot of things that have been yelled at your rallies
column14: Senator Obama
column15: that I'm not happy about either.  In fact
column16: some T-shirts that are very...

column1: ... unacceptable. So the point is -- the point is that I have repudiated every time someone's been out of line
column2: whether they've been part of my campaign or not
column3: and I will continue to do that. But the fact is that we need to absolutely not stand for the kind of things that have been going on. I haven't.

column2: look
column3: Bob
column4: as I said...

column2: here's what I would say. I mean
column3: we can have a debate back and forth about the merits of each other's campaigns. I suspect we won't agree here tonight. What I think is most important is that we recognize that to solve the key problems that we're facing
column4: if we're going to solve two wars
column5: the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression
column6: if we can -- if we're going to focus on lifting wages that have declined over the last eight years and create jobs here in America
column7: then Democrats
column8: independents and Republicans
column9: we're going to have to be able to work together.

column1: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable. And it means that we can have tough
column2: vigorous debates around issues. What we can't do
column3: I think
column4: is try to characterize each other as bad people. And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long. And I think...

column2: Bob
column3: you asked me a direct question.

column2: real quick. Mr. Ayers
column3: I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you
column4: we need to know the full extent of that relationship. We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN
column5: who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country
column6: maybe destroying the fabric of democracy. The same front outfit organization that your campaign gave $832
column7: 000 for ""lighting and site selection."" So all of these things need to be examined
column8: of course.

column2: I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention. In fact
column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago
column4: when I was 8 years old
column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends
column6: Mr. Annenberg.  Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois
column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican
column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column2: again
column3: while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation
column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.

column2: real quick. Mr. Ayers
column3: I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you
column4: we need to know the full extent of that relationship. We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN

column2: I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention. In fact
column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago
column4: when I was 8 years old
column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends
column6: Mr. Annenberg.  Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois
column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican
column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.

column9: we're going to have to be able to work together.

column1: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable. And it means that we can have tough
column2: vigorous debates around issues. What we can't do
column3: I think
column4: is try to characterize each other as bad people. And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long. And I think...

column2: Bob
column3: you asked me a direct question.

column2: real quick. Mr. Ayers
column3: I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you
column4: we need to know the full extent of that relationship. We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN
column5: who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country
column6: maybe destroying the fabric of democracy. The same front outfit organization that your campaign gave $832
column7: 000 for ""lighting and site selection."" So all of these things need to be examined
column8: of course.

column2: I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention. In fact
column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago
column4: when I was 8 years old
column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends
column6: Mr. Annenberg.  Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois
column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican
column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column2: again
column3: while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation
column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.

column31: ""I will sit down and negotiate with John McCain about public financing before I make a decision
column32: you didn't tell the American people the truth because you didn't.  And that's -- that's -- that's an unfortunate part. Now we have the highest spending by Senator Obama's campaign than any time since Watergate.

column15: if we keep on talking about the economic crisis

column17: so we need to change the subject.  And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy

So the fact is that Senator Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics

column4: if we're going to solve two wars

column1: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable. And it means that we can have tough
column2: vigorous debates around issues. What we can't do

column4: is try to characterize each other as bad people. And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long. And I think...

column2: real quick. Mr. Ayers
column3: I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you
column4: we need to know the full extent of that relationship. We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN
column5: who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country
column6: maybe destroying the fabric of democracy. The same front outfit organization that your campaign gave $832
column7: 000 for ""lighting and site selection."" So all of these things need to be examined
column8: of course.

column2: I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention. In fact
column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago
column4: when I was 8 years old
column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends
column6: Mr. Annenberg.  Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois
column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican
column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column2: again
column3: while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation
column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.

column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column2: again
column3: while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation
column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.

column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago

column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago

column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends

column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican

column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now

column14: it's gotten pretty tough. And I regret some of the negative aspects of both campaigns. But the fact is that it has taken many turns which I think are unacceptable.  One of them happened just the other day
column15: when a man I admire and respect -- I've written about him -- Congressman John Lewis
column16: an American hero

column20: George Wallace. That

column26: I have repudiated them. I hope that Senator Obama will repudiate those remarks that were made by Congressman John Lewis
column27: very unfair and totally inappropriate.  So I want to tell you

column29: Senator Obama
column30: when he said -- and he signed a piece of paper that said he would take public financing for his campaign if I did -- that was back when he was a long-shot candidate -- you didn't keep your word.  And when you looked into the camera in a debate with Senator Clinton and said
column31: ""I will sit down and negotiate with John McCain about public financing before I make a decision
column32: you didn't tell the American people the truth because you didn't.  And that's -- that's -- that's an unfortunate part. Now we have the highest spending by Senator Obama's campaign than any time since Watergate.

column2: look
column3: you know
column4: I think that we expect presidential campaigns to be tough. I think that
column5: if you look at the record and the impressions of the American people -- Bob
column6: your network just did a poll
column7: showing that two-thirds of the American people think that Senator McCain is running a negative campaign versus one-third of mine. And 100 percent
column8: John
column9: of your ads -- 100 percent of them have been negative.

column2: now
column3: I think the American people are less interested in our hurt feelings during the course of the campaign than addressing the issues that matter to them so deeply. And there is nothing wrong with us having a vigorous debate like we're having tonight about health care

column5: about tax policy. That's the stuff that campaigns should be made of.  The notion
column6: though

column11: well
column12: I don't mind being attacked for the next three weeks.  What the American people can't afford
column13: though
column14: is four more years of failed economic policies. And what they deserve over the next four weeks is that we talk about what's most pressing to them: the economic crisis.  Senator McCain's own campaign said publicly last week that
column15: if we keep on talking about the economic crisis
column16: we lose
column17: so we need to change the subject.  And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy
column18: devoted to talking about health care
column19: devoted to talking about energy
column20: and figuring out how the American people can send their kids to college. And that is something that I would welcome. But it requires
column22: a recognition that politics as usual
column23: as been practiced over the last several years
column24: is not solving the big problems here in America.

column2: if you'll turn on the television

column1: Every other ad -- ever other ad was an attack ad on my health care plan. And any objective observer has said it's not true. You're running ads right now that say that I oppose federal funding for stem cell research. I don't. You're running ads that misportray completely my position on immigration. So the fact is that Senator Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics
column2: going back to the beginning
column3: amounts of money in negative attack ads on me.  And of course
column4: I've been talking about the economy. Of course
column5: I've talked to people like Joe the plumber and tell him that I'm not going to spread his wealth around. I'm going to let him keep his wealth. And of course
column6: we're talking about positive plan of action to restore this economy and restore jobs in America.  That's what my campaign is all about and that's what it'll continue to be all about.  But again
column7: I did not hear a repudiation of Congressman...

column13: didn't stop

column10: and that's what I have been trying to focus on this entire campaign.

column2: here's what I would say. I mean
column3: we can have a debate back and forth about the merits of each other's campaigns. I suspect we won't agree here tonight. What I think is most important is that we recognize that to solve the key problems that we're facing
column4: if we're going to solve two wars
column5: the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression
column6: if we can -- if we're going to focus on lifting wages that have declined over the last eight years and create jobs here in America
column7: then Democrats
column8: independents and Republicans
column9: we're going to have to be able to work together.

column1: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable. And it means that we can have tough
column2: vigorous debates around issues. What we can't do
column3: I think
column4: is try to characterize each other as bad people. And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long. And I think...

column2: Bob
column3: you asked me a direct question.

column2: real quick. Mr. Ayers
column3: I don't care about an old washed-up terrorist. But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you
column4: we need to know the full extent of that relationship. We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN
column5: who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country
column6: maybe destroying the fabric of democracy. The same front outfit organization that your campaign gave $832
column7: 000 for ""lighting and site selection."" So all of these things need to be examined
column8: of course.

column2: I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention. In fact
column3: Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks. This has been their primary focus. So let's get the record straight. Bill Ayers is a professor of education in Chicago.  Forty years ago
column4: when I was 8 years old
column5: he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group. I have roundly condemned those acts. Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends
column6: Mr. Annenberg.  Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois
column7: the president of Northwestern University
column8: who happens to be a Republican
column9: the president of The Chicago Tribune
column10: a Republican- leaning newspaper.  Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign. He has never been involved in this campaign. And he will not advise me in the White House. So that's Mr. Ayers.  Now
column11: with respect to ACORN
column12: ACORN is a community organization. Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks
column13: and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people
column14: they just filled out a bunch of names.  It had nothing to do with us. We were not involved. The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.  Now
column15: the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.  Let me tell you who I associate with. On economic policy
column16: I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker. If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy
column17: I associate myself with my running mate
column18: Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar
column19: the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column20: or General Jim Jones
column21: the former supreme allied commander of NATO.  Those are the people
column22: Democrats and Republicans
column23: who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House. And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign
column25: says more about your campaign than it says about me.

column2: again
column3: while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation
column4: you and Mr. Ayers
column5: together
column6: you sent $230
column7: 000 to ACORN. So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.

column1: And the facts are facts and records are records.
And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more
column2: and he had a long association with him. It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment. And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track
column3: about creating jobs
column4: about a brighter future for America. And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy. And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.
