column1: I think that in ten years
column2: we can reduce our dependence so that we no longer have to import oil from the Middle East or Venezuela. I think that's about a realistic timeframe. And this is the most important issue that our future economy is going to face. Obviously
column3: we've got an immediate crisis right now. But nothing is more important than us no longer borrowing $700 billion or more from China and sending it to Saudi Arabia. It's mortgaging our children's future.  Now
column4: from the start of this campaign
column5: I've identified this as one of my top priorities and here is what I think we have to do.  Number one
column6: we do need to expand domestic production and that means
column7: for example
column8: telling the oil companies the 68 million acres that they currently have leased that they're not drilling
column9: use them or lose them.  And I think that we should look at offshore drilling and implement it in a way that allows us to get some additional oil. But understand
column10: we only have three to four percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil
column11: which means that we can't drill our way out of the problem.  That's why I've focused on putting resources into solar
column12: wind
column13: biodiesel
column14: geothermal. These have been priorities of mine since I got to the Senate
column15: and it is absolutely critical that we develop a high fuel efficient car that's built not in Japan and not in South Korea
column16: but built here in the United States of America.  We invented the auto industry and the fact that we have fallen so far behind is something that we have to work on.

column1: Now I just want to make one last point because Senator McCain mentioned NAFTA and the issue of trade and that actually bears on this issue. I believe in free trade. But I also believe that for far too long
column2: certainly during the course of the Bush administration with the support of Senator McCain
column3: the attitude has been that any trade agreement is a good trade agreement. And NAFTA doesn't have -- did not have enforceable labor agreements and environmental agreements. And what I said was we should include those and make them enforceable. In the same way that we should enforce rules against China manipulating its currency to make our exports more expensive and their exports to us cheaper.  And when it comes to South Korea
column4: we've got a trade agreement up right now
column5: they are sending hundreds of thousands of South Korean cars into the United States. That's all good. We can only get 4
column7: 000 into South Korea. That is not free trade. We've got to have a president who is going to be advocating on behalf of American businesses and American workers and I make no apology for that.

column2: you know
column3: I admire so much Senator Obama's eloquence. And you really have to pay attention to words. He said
column4: we will look at offshore drilling. Did you get that? Look at. We can offshore drill now. We've got to do it now. We will reduce the cost of a barrel of oil because we show the world that we have a supply of our own. It's doable. The technology is there and we have to drill now. Now
column5: on the subject of free trade agreements. I am a free trader. And I need -- we need to have education and training programs for displaced workers that work
column6: going to our community colleges.  But let me give you another example of a free trade agreement that Senator Obama opposes. Right now
column7: because of previous agreements
column8: some made by President Clinton
column9: the goods and products that we send to Colombia
column10: which is our largest agricultural importer of our products
column11: is -- there's a billion dollars that we -- our businesses have paid so far in order to get our goods in there.  Because of previous agreements
column12: their goods and products come into our country for free. So Senator Obama
column13: who has never traveled south of our border
column14: opposes the Colombia Free Trade Agreement. The same country that's helping us try to stop the flow of drugs into our country that's killing young Americans.  And also the country that just freed three Americans that will help us create jobs in America because they will be a market for our goods and products without having to pay -- without us having to pay the billions of dollars -- the billion dollars and more that we've already paid.  Free trade with Colombia is something that's a no-brainer. But maybe you ought to travel down there and visit them and maybe you could understand it a lot better.

column2: I understand it pretty well. The history in Colombia right now is that labor leaders have been targeted for assassination on a fairly consistent basis and there have not been prosecutions. And what I have said
column3: because the free trade -- the trade agreement itself does have labor and environmental protections
column4: but we have to stand for human rights and we have to make sure that violence isn't being perpetrated against workers who are just trying to organize for their rights
column5: which is why
column6: for example
column7: I supported the Peruvian Free Trade Agreement which was a well-structured agreement.  But I think that the important point is we've got to have a president who understands the benefits of free trade but also is going to enforce unfair trade agreements and is going to stand up to other countries.  And the last point I'll make
column8: because we started on energy. When I talked about the automakers
column9: they are obviously getting hammered right now. They were already having a tough time because of high gas prices. And now with the financial crisis
column10: car dealerships are closing and people can't get car loans.  That's why I think it's important for us to get loan guarantees to the automakers
column11: but we do have to hold them responsible as well to start producing the highly fuel-efficient cars of the future.  And Detroit had dragged its feet too long in terms of getting that done. It's going to be one of my highest priorities because transportation accounts for about 30 percent of our total energy consumption.  If we can get that right
column12: then we can move in a direction not only of energy independence
column13: but we can create 5 million new jobs all across America
column14: including in the heartland where we can retool some of these plants to make these highly fuel-efficient cars and also to make wind turbines and solar panels
column15: the kinds of clean energy approaches that should be the driver of our economy for the next century.

column2: let me just said that that this is -- he -- Senator Obama doesn't want a free trade agreement with our best ally in the region but wants to sit down across the table without precondition to -- with Hugo Chavez
column3: the guy who has been helping FARC
column4: the terrorist organization. Free trade between ourselves and Colombia
column5: I just recited to you the benefits of concluding that agreement
column6: a billion dollars of American dollars that could have gone to creating jobs and businesses in the United States
column7: opening up those markets.  So I don't -- I don't think there's any doubt that Senator Obama wants to restrict trade and he wants to raise taxes. And the last president of the United States that tried that was Herbert Hoover
column8: and we went from a deep recession into a depression.  We're not going to follow that path while I'm -- when I'm president of the United States.

column2: and that's exactly what my plan does. Look
column3: as I travel around the country
column4: this is the issue that will break your heart over and over again. Just yesterday
column5: I was in Toledo shaking some hands in a line. Two women
column6: both of them probably in their mid- to late-50s
column7: had just been laid off of their plant. Neither of them have health insurance.  And they were desperate for some way of getting coverage
column8: because
column9: understandably
column10: they're worried that
column11: if they get sick
column12: they could go bankrupt.  So here's what my plan does. If you have health insurance
column13: then you don't have to do anything. If you've got health insurance through your employer
column14: you can keep your health insurance
column16: keep your plan.  The only thing we're going to try to do is lower costs so that those cost savings are passed onto you. And we estimate we can cut the average family's premium by about $2
column17: 500 per year. If you don't have health insurance
column18: then what we're going to do is to provide you the option of buying into the same kind of federal pool that both Senator McCain and I enjoy as federal employees
column19: which will give you high-quality care
column20: choice of doctors
column22: because so many people are part of this insured group.  We're going to make sure that insurance companies can't discriminate on the basis of pre-existing conditions. We'll negotiate with the drug companies for the cheapest available price on drugs.  We are going to invest in information technology to eliminate bureaucracy and make the system more efficient.  And we are going to make sure that we manage chronic illnesses
column23: like diabetes and heart disease
column25: but could be prevented. We've got to put more money into preventive care.  This will cost some money on the front end
column26: but over the long term this is the only way that not only are we going to make families healthy
column27: but it's also how we're going to save the federal budget
column28: because we can't afford these escalating costs.

column2: it is a terribly painful situation for Americans. They're seeing their premiums
column3: their co-pays go up. Forty-seven million Americans are without health insurance in America today. And it really is the cost
column4: the escalating costs of health care that are inflicting such pain on working families and people across this country. And I am convinced we need to do a lot of things.  We need to put health care records online. The V.A. does that. That will -- that will reduce costs. We need to have more community health centers. We need to have walk-in clinics.  The rise of obesity amongst young Americans is one of the most alarming statistics that there is. We should have physical fitness programs and nutrition programs in schools. Every parent should know what's going on there.  We -- we need to have -- we need to have employers reward employees who join health clubs and practice wellness and fitness.  But I want to give every American family a $5
column5: 000 refundable tax credit. Take it and get anywhere in America the health care that you wish.  Now
column6: my old buddy
column7: Joe
column8: Joe the plumber
column9: is out there. Now
column10: Joe
column11: Senator Obama's plan
column12: if you're a small business and you are able -- and your -- the guy that sells to you will not have his capital gains tax increase
column13: which Senator Obama wants
column14: if you're out there
column16: and you've got employees
column17: and you've got kids
column18: if you don't get -- adopt the health care plan that Senator Obama mandates
column19: he's going to fine you.

column2: Senator Obama
column3: I'd like -- still like to know what that fine is going to be
column4: and I don't think that Joe right now wants to pay a fine when he is seeing such difficult times in America's economy. Senator Obama wants to set up health care bureaucracies
column5: take over the health care of America through -- as he said
column6: his object is a single payer system.  If you like that
column7: you'll love Canada and England. So the point is...

column1: It is not and I just described it...

column2: you stated it.

column1: I just described what my plan is. And I'm happy to talk to you
column2: Joe
column3: too
column4: if you're out there. Here's your fine -- zero. You won't pay a fine
column5: because...

column2: because as I said in our last debate and I'll repeat
column3: John
column4: I exempt small businesses from the requirement for large businesses that can afford to provide health care to their employees
column5: but are not doing it. I exempt small businesses from having to pay into a kitty. But large businesses that can afford it
column6: we've got a choice. Either they provide health insurance to their employees or somebody has to.  Right now
column7: what happens is those employees get dumped into either the Medicaid system
column8: which taxpayers pick up
column9: or they're going to the emergency room for uncompensated care
column10: which everybody picks up in their premiums.  The average family is paying an additional $900 a year in higher premiums because of the uninsured.  So here's what we do. We exempt small businesses. In fact
column11: what
column12: Joe
column13: if you want to do the right thing with your employees and you want to provide them health insurance
column14: we'll give you a 50 percent credit so that you will actually be able to afford it.  If you don't have health insurance or you want to buy into a group plan
column15: you will be able to buy into the plan that I just described.  Now
column16: what we haven't talked about is Senator McCain's plan. He says he's going to give you all a $5
column17: 000 tax credit. That sounds pretty good. And you can go out and buy your own insurance.  Here's the problem -- that for about 20 million people
column18: you may find yourselves no longer having employer-based health insurance. This is because younger people might be able to get health insurance for $5
column20: young and healthy folks.  Older folks
column22: what's going to end up happening is that you're going to be the only ones left in your employer-based system
column23: your employers won't be able to afford it.  And once you're out on your own with this $5
column25: Senator McCain
column26: for the first time
column27: is going to be taxing the health care benefits that you have from your employer.  And this is your plan
column28: John. For the first time in history
column29: you will be taxing people's health care benefits.  By the way
column32: 000 and it's going to cost you $12
column34: that's a loss for you.  Last point about Senator McCain's plan is that insurers right now
column35: the main restrictions on what they do is primarily state law and
column37: those rules would be stripped away and you would start seeing a lot more insurance companies cherry-picking and excluding people from coverage.  That
column39: is a mistake and I think that this is a fundamental difference in our campaign and how we would approach health care.

column2: Joe
column3: you're rich
column4: congratulations
column5: because what Joe wanted to do was buy the business that he's been working for 10-12 hours a day
column6: seven days a week
column7: and you said that you wanted to spread the wealth
column8: but -- in other words
column9: take Joe's money and then you decide what to do with it. Now
column10: Joe
column11: you're rich
column12: congratulations
column13: and you will then fall into the category where you'll have to pay a fine if you don't provide health insurance that Senator Obama mandates
column14: not the kind that you think is best for your family
column16: your employees
column17: but the kind that he mandates for you.  That's big government at its best. Now
column18: 95 percent of the people in America will receive more money under my plan because they will receive not only their present benefits
column19: which may be taxed
column20: which will be taxed
column22: 000 onto it
column23: except for those people who have the gold-plated Cadillac insurance policies that have to do with cosmetic surgery and transplants and all of those kinds of things.  And the good thing about this is they'll be able to go across America. The average cost of a health care insurance plan in America today is $5
column25: 000 to take with them wherever they want to go
column26: and this will give them affordability.  This will give them availability. This will give them a chance to choose their own futures
column27: not have Senator Obama and government decide that for them.  This really gets down to the fundamental difference in our philosophies. If you notice that in all of this proposal
column28: Senator -- government wants -- Senator Obama wants government to do the job.  Senator Obama wants government to do the job. I want
column29: Joe

column1: I want to leave money in your pocket. I want you to be able to choose the health care for you and your family. That's what I'm all about. And we've got too much government and too much spending and the government is -- the size of government has grown by 40 percent in the last eight years. We can't afford that in the next eight years and Senator Obama
column2: with the Democrats in charge of Congress
column3: things have gotten worse. Have you noticed
column4: they've been in charge the last two years.

column1: Very briefly. You all just heard my plan. If you've got an employer-based health care plan
column2: you keep it. Now
column3: under Senator McCain's plan there is a strong risk that people would lose their employer-based health care. That's the choice you'll have is having your employer no longer provide you health care. And don't take my word for it. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce
column4: which generally doesn't support a lot of Democrats
column5: said that this plan could lead to the unraveling of the employer-based health care system.  All I want to do
column6: if you've already got health care
column7: is lower your costs. That includes you
column8: Joe.

column4: Joe Biden
column5: I think
column6: is one of the finest public servants that has served in this country. It's not just that he has some of the best foreign policy credentials of anybody. And Democrats and Republicans alike
column7: I think
column8: acknowledge his expertise there. But it's also that his entire life he has never forgotten where he came from
column9: coming from Scranton
column10: fighting on behalf of working families
column11: remembering what it's like to see his father lose his job and go through a downward spiral economically.  And
column12: as a consequence
column13: his consistent pattern throughout his career is to fight for the little guy. That's what he's done when it comes to economic policies that will help working families get a leg up.  That's what he's done when it comes to
column14: for example
column16: the Violence Against Women's Act. Joe has always made sure that he is fighting on behalf of working families
column17: and I think he shares my core values and my sense of where the country needs to go.  Because after eight years of failed policies
column18: he and I both agree that what we're going to have to do is to reprioritize
column19: make sure that we're investing in the American people
column20: give tax cuts not to the wealthiest corporations
column21: but give them to small businesses and give them to individuals who are struggling right now
column22: make sure that we finally get serious about energy independence
column23: something that has been languishing in Washington for 30 years
column24: and make sure that our kids get a great education and can afford to go to college.  So
column25: on the key issues that are of importance to American families
column26: Joe Biden's always been on the right side
column27: and I think he will make an outstanding president if
column28: heaven forbid
column29: something happened to me.

column2: Americans have gotten to know Sarah Palin. They know that she's a role model to women and other -- and reformers all over America. She's a reformer. She is -- she took on a governor who was a member of her own party when she ran for governor. When she was the head of their energy and natural resources board
column3: she saw corruption
column4: she resigned and said
column5: ""This can't go on."" She's given money back to the taxpayers. She's cut the size of government. She negotiated with the oil companies and faced them down
column6: a $40 billion pipeline of natural gas that's going to relieve the energy needs of the United -- of what they call the lower 48.  She's a reformer through and through. And it's time we had that bresh of freth air (sic) -- breath of fresh air coming into our nation's capital and sweep out the old-boy network and the cronyism that's been so much a part of it that I've fought against for all these years.  She'll be my partner. She understands reform. And
column7: by the way
column8: she also understands special-needs families. She understands that autism is on the rise
column9: that we've got to find out what's causing it
column10: and we've got to reach out to these families
column11: and help them
column12: and give them the help they need as they raise these very special needs children.  She understands that better than almost any American that I know. I'm proud of her.  And she has ignited our party and people all over America that have never been involved in the political process. And I can't tell how proud I am of her and her family.  Her husband's a pretty tough guy
column13: by the way
column14: too.

column12: I think
column13: the kind of use of the scalpel that we want to make sure that we're funding some of those programs.

column1: I think that in ten years
column2: we can reduce our dependence so that we no longer have to import oil from the Middle East or Venezuela. I think that's about a realistic timeframe. And this is the most important issue that our future economy is going to face. Obviously
column3: we've got an immediate crisis right now. But nothing is more important than us no longer borrowing $700 billion or more from China and sending it to Saudi Arabia. It's mortgaging our children's future.  Now
column4: from the start of this campaign
column5: I've identified this as one of my top priorities and here is what I think we have to do.  Number one
column6: we do need to expand domestic production and that means
column7: for example
column8: telling the oil companies the 68 million acres that they currently have leased that they're not drilling
column9: use them or lose them.  And I think that we should look at offshore drilling and implement it in a way that allows us to get some additional oil. But understand
column10: we only have three to four percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil
column11: which means that we can't drill our way out of the problem.  That's why I've focused on putting resources into solar
column12: wind
column13: biodiesel
column14: geothermal. These have been priorities of mine since I got to the Senate

column1: Now I just want to make one last point because Senator McCain mentioned NAFTA and the issue of trade and that actually bears on this issue. I believe in free trade. But I also believe that for far too long
column2: certainly during the course of the Bush administration with the support of Senator McCain
column3: the attitude has been that any trade agreement is a good trade agreement. And NAFTA doesn't have -- did not have enforceable labor agreements and environmental agreements. And what I said was we should include those and make them enforceable. In the same way that we should enforce rules against China manipulating its currency to make our exports more expensive and their exports to us cheaper.  And when it comes to South Korea
column4: we've got a trade agreement up right now
column5: they are sending hundreds of thousands of South Korean cars into the United States. That's all good. We can only get 4
column7: 000 into South Korea. That is not free trade. We've got to have a president who is going to be advocating on behalf of American businesses and American workers and I make no apology for that.

column2: you know
column3: I admire so much Senator Obama's eloquence. And you really have to pay attention to words. He said
column4: we will look at offshore drilling. Did you get that? Look at. We can offshore drill now. We've got to do it now. We will reduce the cost of a barrel of oil because we show the world that we have a supply of our own. It's doable. The technology is there and we have to drill now. Now
column5: on the subject of free trade agreements. I am a free trader. And I need -- we need to have education and training programs for displaced workers that work
column6: going to our community colleges.  But let me give you another example of a free trade agreement that Senator Obama opposes. Right now
column7: because of previous agreements
column8: some made by President Clinton
column9: the goods and products that we send to Colombia
column10: which is our largest agricultural importer of our products
column11: is -- there's a billion dollars that we -- our businesses have paid so far in order to get our goods in there.  Because of previous agreements
column12: their goods and products come into our country for free. So Senator Obama
column13: who has never traveled south of our border
column14: opposes the Colombia Free Trade Agreement. The same country that's helping us try to stop the flow of drugs into our country that's killing young Americans.  And also the country that just freed three Americans that will help us create jobs in America because they will be a market for our goods and products without having to pay -- without us having to pay the billions of dollars -- the billion dollars and more that we've already paid.  Free trade with Colombia is something that's a no-brainer. But maybe you ought to travel down there and visit them and maybe you could understand it a lot better.

column2: I understand it pretty well. The history in Colombia right now is that labor leaders have been targeted for assassination on a fairly consistent basis and there have not been prosecutions. And what I have said
column3: because the free trade -- the trade agreement itself does have labor and environmental protections
column4: but we have to stand for human rights and we have to make sure that violence isn't being perpetrated against workers who are just trying to organize for their rights
column5: which is why
column6: for example
column7: I supported the Peruvian Free Trade Agreement which was a well-structured agreement.  But I think that the important point is we've got to have a president who understands the benefits of free trade but also is going to enforce unfair trade agreements and is going to stand up to other countries.  And the last point I'll make
column8: because we started on energy. When I talked about the automakers
column9: they are obviously getting hammered right now. They were already having a tough time because of high gas prices. And now with the financial crisis
column10: car dealerships are closing and people can't get car loans.  That's why I think it's important for us to get loan guarantees to the automakers
column11: but we do have to hold them responsible as well to start producing the highly fuel-efficient cars of the future.  And Detroit had dragged its feet too long in terms of getting that done. It's going to be one of my highest priorities because transportation accounts for about 30 percent of our total energy consumption.  If we can get that right
column12: then we can move in a direction not only of energy independence
column13: but we can create 5 million new jobs all across America
column14: including in the heartland where we can retool some of these plants to make these highly fuel-efficient cars and also to make wind turbines and solar panels
column15: the kinds of clean energy approaches that should be the driver of our economy for the next century.

column16: keep your plan.  The only thing we're going to try to do is lower costs so that those cost savings are passed onto you. And we estimate we can cut the average family's premium by about $2

column22: because so many people are part of this insured group.  We're going to make sure that insurance companies can't discriminate on the basis of pre-existing conditions. We'll negotiate with the drug companies for the cheapest available price on drugs.  We are going to invest in information technology to eliminate bureaucracy and make the system more efficient.  And we are going to make sure that we manage chronic illnesses
column23: like diabetes and heart disease
column25: but could be prevented. We've got to put more money into preventive care.  This will cost some money on the front end
column26: but over the long term this is the only way that not only are we going to make families healthy
column27: but it's also how we're going to save the federal budget
column28: because we can't afford these escalating costs.

column2: it is a terribly painful situation for Americans. They're seeing their premiums

We need to put health care records online. The V.A. does that. That will -- that will reduce costs. We need to have more community health centers. We need to have walk-in clinics.  The rise of obesity amongst young Americans is one of the most alarming statistics that there is. We should have physical fitness programs and nutrition programs in schools. Every parent should know what's going on there.  We -- we need to have -- we need to have employers reward employees who join health clubs and practice wellness and fitness. of the best foreign policy credentials of anybody', 'And Democrats and Republicans alike, I think, acknowledge his expertise there', 'But its also that his entire life he has never forgotten where he consequence, his consistent pattern throughout his career is to fight for the little guy', 'Thats what hes done when it comes to economic policies that will help working families get a leg up', 'Thats think he shares my core values and my sense of where the country needs to go', 'Because after eight years of failed policies, he and I both agree that what were going to have to do is to reprioritize, make sure that we finally get serious about energy independence, something that has been languishing in Washington for 30 years, and make sure that our kids get a great education and can afford to go to college', 'So, on the key issues that are of importance to American families, Joe Bidens always been on the right side, and I think he will make an outstanding president if, heaven forbid, ignited our party and people all over America that have never been involved in the political process', 'And I cant tell how proud I am of her and her family', 'Her husbands a pretty tough guy, by the against the first Gulf War', 'He voted against it and, obviously, we had to take Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait or it wouldve threatened the Middle Eastern world supply', 'In Iraq, he had this to China', 'You dont tell countries youre going to unilaterally renegotiate agreements with them', 'We can eliminate our dependence on foreign oil by building 45 new nuclear plants, power plants, right away', 'We can store and we can reprocess', 'Senator Obama will tell you, in the  as the extreme environmentalists do, it has to be safe', 'Look, weve sailed Navy ships around the world for 60 development of flex fuel, hybrid, clean coal technology, clean coal technology is key in the heartland of America thats hurting rather badly', 'So I think we can easily, within seven, eight, ten years, if we put our minds to it, we can eliminate our dependence on the places in the world that harm our national security if we dont achieve our independence', 'I think that in ten years, we can reduce our dependence so that we no longer have to import oil from the Middle East or Venezuela', 'I think thats about a realistic timeframe', 'And this is the most important issue that our future that we should look at offshore drilling and implement it in a way that allows us to get some additional oil', 'But understand, we only have three to four percent of the worlds oil reserves and we use agreements, some made by President Clinton, the goods and products that we send to Colombia, which is our largest agricultural importer of our products, is  theres a billion dollars that we  our businesses have paid so far in order to get our goods in there', 'Because of previous agreements, their goods and products come into our country for free', 'So Senator Obama, who has never traveled consistent basis and there have not been prosecutions', 'And what I have said, because the free trade  the trade agreement itself does have labor and environmental protections, but we have to stand Free Trade Agreement which was a wellstructured agreement', 'But I think that the important point is weve got to have a president who understands the benefits of free trade but also is going to why I think its important for us to get loan guarantees to the automakers, but we do have to hold them responsible as well to start producing the highly fuelefficient cars of the future', 'And Detroit had dragged its feet too long in terms of getting that done', 'Its going to be one of my highest priorities because transportation accounts for about 30 percent of our total energy consumption', 'If we can get that right, then we can move in a direction not only of energy independence, but we can create 5 million new jobs all across America, including in the heartland where we can retool some of these plants to make these highly fuelefficient cars and also to make wind turbines and solar panels, the kinds of clean energy approaches that should be the driver of our economy for the next billion dollars of American dollars that could have gone to creating jobs and businesses in the United States, opening up those markets', 'So I dont  I dont think theres any doubt that Senator Obama wants to restrict trade and he wants to raise taxes', 'And the last president of the United States that tried that was Herbert Hoover, and we went from a deep recession into a depression', 'Were not going to follow that path while Im  when Im president of the United States', 'Weve got to do both, and thats exactly what my plan does', 'Look, as I travel around the country, this is the issue that plant', 'Neither of them have health insurance', 'And they were desperate for some way of getting coverage, because, understandably, theyre worried that, if they get sick, they could go bankrupt', 'So heres what my plan does', 'If you have health insurance, then you dont have to do anything', 'If youve got health insurance through your employer, you can keep your health insurance, keep your choice of doctor, keep your plan', 'The only thing were going to try to do is lower costs so that those cost savings are passed onto you', 'And we estimate we can cut the average familys premium by about $2,500 per year', 'If you dont have health insurance, then what were going to do is to provide you the option of buying into the same kind of federal pool that both Senator McCain and I enjoy as insurance for $5,000, young and healthy folks', 'Older folks, less healthy folks, whats going to end up happening is that youre going to be the only ones left in your employerbased system, your employers wont be able to afford it', 'And once youre out on your own with this $5,000 credit, Senator McCain, for the first time, is going to be taxing the health care benefits that you have from $5,000 and its going to cost you $12,000, thats a loss for you', 'Last point about Senator McCains plan is that insurers right now, the main restrictions on what they do is primarily state law and, under Senator McCains plan, those rules would be stripped away and you would start seeing a lot more insurance companies cherrypicking and excluding people from coverage', 'That, I think, is a mistake and I think that this is a fundamental difference in our campaign and how we would approach health care', 'Hey, Joe, youre rich, congratulations, because what Joe wanted to do was buy the business Joe, youre rich, congratulations, and you will then fall into the category where youll have to pay a fine if you dont provide health insurance that Senator Obama mandates, not the kind that you think is best for your family, your children, your employees, but the kind that he mandates for you', 'Thats big government at its best', 'Now, 95 percent of the people in America will receive more money under my plan because they will receive not only their present benefits, which may be taxed, which will be taxed, but then you add $5,000 onto it, except for those people who have the goldplated Cadillac insurance policies that have to do with cosmetic surgery and transplants and all of those kinds of things', 'And the good thing about this is theyll be able to go across America', 'The average cost of a health care insurance plan in America today is $5,800', 'Im going to give them $5,000 to take with them wherever they want to go, and this will give them affordability', 'This will our philosophies', 'If you notice that in all of this proposal, Senator  government wants  Senator Obama wants government to do the job', 'Senator Obama wants government to do the job', 'I want, Joe, plan, you keep it', 'Now, under Senator McCains plan there is a strong risk that people would lose their employerbased health care', 'Thats the choice youll have is having your employer no longer column4: Joe Biden
column5: I think
column6: is one of the finest public servants that has served in this country. It's not just that he has some of the best foreign policy credentials of anybody. And Democrats and Republicans alike
column7: I think
column8: acknowledge his expertise there. But it's also that his entire life he has never forgotten where he came from
column9: coming from Scranton
column10: fighting on behalf of working families
column11: remembering what it's like to see his father lose his job and go through a downward spiral economically.  And
column12: as a consequence
column13: his consistent pattern throughout his career is to fight for the little guy. That's what he's done when it comes to economic policies that will help working families get a leg up.  That's what he's done when it comes to
column14: for example
column16: the Violence Against Women's Act. Joe has always made sure that he is fighting on behalf of working families
column17: and I think he shares my core values and my sense of where the country needs to go.  Because after eight years of failed policies
column18: he and I both agree that what we're going to have to do is to reprioritize
column19: make sure that we're investing in the American people
column20: give tax cuts not to the wealthiest corporations
column21: but give them to small businesses and give them to individuals who are struggling right now
column22: make sure that we finally get serious about energy independence
column23: something that has been languishing in Washington for 30 years
column24: and make sure that our kids get a great education and can afford to go to college.  So
column25: on the key issues that are of importance to American families
column26: Joe Biden's always been on the right side
column27: and I think he will make an outstanding president if
column28: heaven forbid
column29: something happened to me.

column2: Americans have gotten to know Sarah Palin. They know that she's a role model to women and other -- and reformers all over America. She's a reformer. She is -- she took on a governor who was a member of her own party when she ran for governor. When she was the head of their energy and natural resources board
column3: she saw corruption
column4: she resigned and said
column5: ""This can't go on."" She's given money back to the taxpayers. She's cut the size of government. She negotiated with the oil companies and faced them down
column6: a $40 billion pipeline of natural gas that's going to relieve the energy needs of the United -- of what they call the lower 48.  She's a reformer through and through. And it's time we had that bresh of freth air (sic) -- breath of fresh air coming into our nation's capital and sweep out the old-boy network and the cronyism that's been so much a part of it that I've fought against for all these years.  She'll be my partner. She understands reform. And
column7: by the way
column8: she also understands special-needs families. She understands that autism is on the rise
column9: that we've got to find out what's causing it

And she has ignited our party and people all over America that have never been involved in the political process. And I can't tell how proud I am of her and her family.  Her husband's a pretty tough guy

column1: I think that in ten years
column2: we can reduce our dependence so that we no longer have to import oil from the Middle East or Venezuela. I think that's about a realistic timeframe. And this is the most important issue that our future economy is going to face. Obviously
column3: we've got an immediate crisis right now. But nothing is more important than us no longer borrowing $700 billion or more from China and sending it to Saudi Arabia. It's mortgaging our children's future.  Now
column4: from the start of this campaign
column5: I've identified this as one of my top priorities and here is what I think we have to do.  Number one
column6: we do need to expand domestic production and that means
column7: for example
column8: telling the oil companies the 68 million acres that they currently have leased that they're not drilling
column9: use them or lose them.  And I think that we should look at offshore drilling and implement it in a way that allows us to get some additional oil. But understand
column10: we only have three to four percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil
column11: which means that we can't drill our way out of the problem.  That's why I've focused on putting resources into solar
column12: wind
column13: biodiesel
column14: geothermal. These have been priorities of mine since I got to the Senate
column15: and it is absolutely critical that we develop a high fuel efficient car that's built not in Japan and not in South Korea
column16: but built here in the United States of America.  We invented the auto industry and the fact that we have fallen so far behind is something that we have to work on.

column1: Now I just want to make one last point because Senator McCain mentioned NAFTA and the issue of trade and that actually bears on this issue. I believe in free trade. But I also believe that for far too long
column2: certainly during the course of the Bush administration with the support of Senator McCain
column3: the attitude has been that any trade agreement is a good trade agreement. And NAFTA doesn't have -- did not have enforceable labor agreements and environmental agreements. And what I said was we should include those and make them enforceable. In the same way that we should enforce rules against China manipulating its currency to make our exports more expensive and their exports to us cheaper.  And when it comes to South Korea
column4: we've got a trade agreement up right now
column5: they are sending hundreds of thousands of South Korean cars into the United States. That's all good. We can only get 4
column7: 000 into South Korea. That is not free trade. We've got to have a president who is going to be advocating on behalf of American businesses and American workers and I make no apology for that.

column2: you know
column3: I admire so much Senator Obama's eloquence. And you really have to pay attention to words. He said
column4: we will look at offshore drilling. Did you get that? Look at. We can offshore drill now. We've got to do it now. We will reduce the cost of a barrel of oil because we show the world that we have a supply of our own. It's doable. The technology is there and we have to drill now. Now
column5: on the subject of free trade agreements. I am a free trader. And I need -- we need to have education and training programs for displaced workers that work
column6: going to our community colleges.  But let me give you another example of a free trade agreement that Senator Obama opposes. Right now
column7: because of previous agreements
column8: some made by President Clinton
column9: the goods and products that we send to Colombia
column10: which is our largest agricultural importer of our products
column11: is -- there's a billion dollars that we -- our businesses have paid so far in order to get our goods in there.  Because of previous agreements
column12: their goods and products come into our country for free. So Senator Obama
column13: who has never traveled south of our border
column14: opposes the Colombia Free Trade Agreement. The same country that's helping us try to stop the flow of drugs into our country that's killing young Americans.  And also the country that just freed three Americans that will help us create jobs in America because they will be a market for our goods and products without having to pay -- without us having to pay the billions of dollars -- the billion dollars and more that we've already paid.  Free trade with Colombia is something that's a no-brainer. But maybe you ought to travel down there and visit them and maybe you could understand it a lot better.

column2: I understand it pretty well. The history in Colombia right now is that labor leaders have been targeted for assassination on a fairly consistent basis and there have not been prosecutions. And what I have said
column3: because the free trade -- the trade agreement itself does have labor and environmental protections
column4: but we have to stand for human rights and we have to make sure that violence isn't being perpetrated against workers who are just trying to organize for their rights
column5: which is why
column6: for example
column7: I supported the Peruvian Free Trade Agreement which was a well-structured agreement.  But I think that the important point is we've got to have a president who understands the benefits of free trade but also is going to enforce unfair trade agreements and is going to stand up to other countries.  And the last point I'll make
column8: because we started on energy. When I talked about the automakers
column9: they are obviously getting hammered right now. They were already having a tough time because of high gas prices. And now with the financial crisis
column10: car dealerships are closing and people can't get car loans.  That's why I think it's important for us to get loan guarantees to the automakers
column11: but we do have to hold them responsible as well to start producing the highly fuel-efficient cars of the future.  And Detroit had dragged its feet too long in terms of getting that done. It's going to be one of my highest priorities because transportation accounts for about 30 percent of our total energy consumption.  If we can get that right
column12: then we can move in a direction not only of energy independence
column13: but we can create 5 million new jobs all across America
column14: including in the heartland where we can retool some of these plants to make these highly fuel-efficient cars and also to make wind turbines and solar panels
column15: the kinds of clean energy approaches that should be the driver of our economy for the next century.

column6: a billion dollars of American dollars that could have gone to creating jobs and businesses in the United States
column7: opening up those markets.  So I don't -- I don't think there's any doubt that Senator Obama wants to restrict trade and he wants to raise taxes. And the last president of the United States that tried that was Herbert Hoover
column8: and we went from a deep recession into a depression.  We're not going to follow that path while I'm -- when I'm president of the United States.

column2: and that's exactly what my plan does. Look
column3: as I travel around the country
column4: this is the issue that will break your heart over and over again. Just yesterday
column5: I was in Toledo shaking some hands in a line. Two women
column6: both of them probably in their mid- to late-50s
column7: had just been laid off of their plant. Neither of them have health insurance.  And they were desperate for some way of getting coverage
column8: because
column9: understandably
column10: they're worried that
column11: if they get sick
column12: they could go bankrupt.  So here's what my plan does. If you have health insurance
column13: then you don't have to do anything. If you've got health insurance through your employer
column14: you can keep your health insurance
column16: keep your plan.  The only thing we're going to try to do is lower costs so that those cost savings are passed onto you. And we estimate we can cut the average family's premium by about $2
column17: 500 per year. If you don't have health insurance
column18: then what we're going to do is to provide you the option of buying into the same kind of federal pool that both Senator McCain and I enjoy as federal employees
column19: which will give you high-quality care
column20: choice of doctors
column22: because so many people are part of this insured group.  We're going to make sure that insurance companies can't discriminate on the basis of pre-existing conditions. We'll negotiate with the drug companies for the cheapest available price on drugs.  We are going to invest in information technology to eliminate bureaucracy and make the system more efficient.  And we are going to make sure that we manage chronic illnesses
column23: like diabetes and heart disease
column25: but could be prevented. We've got to put more money into preventive care.  This will cost some money on the front end
column26: but over the long term this is the only way that not only are we going to make families healthy
column27: but it's also how we're going to save the federal budget
column28: because we can't afford these escalating costs.

column2: it is a terribly painful situation for Americans. They're seeing their premiums
column3: their co-pays go up. Forty-seven million Americans are without health insurance in America today. And it really is the cost
column4: the escalating costs of health care that are inflicting such pain on working families and people across this country. And I am convinced we need to do a lot of things.  We need to put health care records online. The V.A. does that. That will -- that will reduce costs. We need to have more community health centers. We need to have walk-in clinics.  The rise of obesity amongst young Americans is one of the most alarming statistics that there is. We should have physical fitness programs and nutrition programs in schools. Every parent should know what's going on there.  We -- we need to have -- we need to have employers reward employees who join health clubs and practice wellness and fitness.  But I want to give every American family a $5
column5: 000 refundable tax credit. Take it and get anywhere in America the health care that you wish.  Now

column32: 000 and it's going to cost you $12

column472: and this will give them affordability.""

column476: 'This really gets down to the fundamental difference in our philosophies.'

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 5)	" I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court. That's not appropriate to do.

column1: I thought it was a bad decision. I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad. I think that decisions should rest in the hands of the states. I'm a federalist. And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test. Now
column2: let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up. Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion. We got together seven Republicans
column3: seven Democrats. You were offered a chance to join. You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of
column4: quote
column5: ""conservative judges.""  I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg. Not because I agreed with their ideology
column6: but because I thought they were qualified and that elections have consequences when presidents are nominated. This is a very important issue we're talking about.  Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees. Elections have consequences. They should be judged on their qualifications. And so that's what I will do.  I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution. And not legislating from the bench.

column1: I would consider anyone in their qualifications. I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications. But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.

column2: I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people. And it is true that this is going to be
column3: I think
column4: one of the most consequential decisions of the next president. It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.  Now I would not provide a litmus test. But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided. I think that abortion is a very difficult issue and it is a moral issue and one that I think good people on both sides can disagree on.  But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families
column5: their doctors
column6: their religious advisers
column7: are in the best position to make this decision. And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum
column8: any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum
column9: any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.

column1: So this is going to be an important issue. I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record
column2: who have the intellect
column3: and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through. I'll just give you one quick example. Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.  For years
column4: she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job. And when she brought a suit
column5: saying equal pay for equal work
column6: the judges said
column7: well
column8: you know
column9: it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit
column10: even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.  We tried to overturn it in the Senate. I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.  I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family
column11: trying to support her family
column12: and is being treated unfairly
column13: then the court has to stand up
column14: if nobody else will. And that's the kind of judge that I want.

column2: that law waived the statute of limitations
column3: which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years. It was a trial lawyer's dream. Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue. We have to change the culture of America. Those of us who are proudly pro-life understand that. And it's got to be courage and compassion that we show to a young woman who's facing this terribly difficult decision.  Senator Obama
column4: as a member of the Illinois State Senate
column5: voted in the Judiciary Committee against a law that would provide immediate medical attention to a child born of a failed abortion. He voted against that.  And then
column6: on the floor of the State Senate
column7: as he did 130 times as a state senator
column8: he voted present.  Then there was another bill before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the state of Illinois not that long ago
column9: where he voted against a ban on partial-birth abortion
column10: one of the late-term abortion
column11: a really -- one of the bad procedures
column12: a terrible. And then
column13: on the floor of the Illinois State Senate
column14: he voted present.  I don't know how you vote ""present"" on some of that. I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America. And that's his record
column15: and that's a matter of his record.  And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade
column16: about the Illinois State Senate. It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted
column17: I think
column18: in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.

column2: let me respond to this. If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant
column3: that's because it's not true. The -- here are the facts. There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade. The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment
column4: which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.  And the Illinois Medical Society
column5: the organization of doctors in Illinois
column6: voted against it. Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care
column7: and there was already a law in the books.  With respect to partial-birth abortion
column8: I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions
column9: partial-birth or otherwise
column10: as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life
column11: and this did not contain that exception.  And I attempted
column12: as many have in the past
column13: of including that so that it is constitutional. And that was rejected
column14: and that's why I voted present
column15: because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.  The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion. This is an issue that -- look
column16: it divides us. And in some ways
column17: it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.  But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say
column18: ""We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth
column19: communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity
column20: and providing options for adoption
column21: and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby.""  Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year
column22: and I think that's where we can find some common ground
column23: because nobody's pro-abortion. I think it's always a tragic situation.

column1: We should try to reduce these circumstances.

column2: the example of the eloquence of Senator Obama. He's health for the mother. You know
column3: that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything. That's the extreme pro-abortion position
column4: quote
column5: ""health."" But
column6: look
column7: Cindy and I are adoptive parents. We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives. We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.  But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn. Of course
column8: we have to come together. Of course
column9: we have to work together
column10: and
column11: of course
column12: it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision
column13: with a compassion
column14: that we'll help them with the adoptive services
column15: with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.

column1: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication
column2: because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power. So we've got to get our education system right. Now
column3: typically
column4: what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform
column5: and I think we need both. In some cases
column6: we are going to have to invest. Early childhood education
column7: which closes the achievement gap
column8: so that every child is prepared for school
column9: every dollar we invest in that
column10: we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores
column11: reduced dropout rates
column12: reduced delinquency rates.  I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers
column13: an army of new teachers
column14: especially in math and science
column16: give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.  And I think it's important for us to make college affordable. Right now
column17: I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college
column18: they are taking on $20
column25: 000 worth of debt
column26: and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields
column27: like basic research in science
column28: for example
column29: thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.  And that's why I've proposed a $4
column32: every year
column33: in exchange for some form of community service
column34: whether it's military service
column36: whether it's working in a community.  If we do those things
column37: then I believe that we can create a better school system.  But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention
column38: and that's parents. We can't do it just in the schools. Parents are going to have to show more responsibility. They've got to turn off the TV set
column39: put away the video games
column41: finally
column42: start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.

column2: it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century. There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle. But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?  So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places
column3: where we have charter schools
column4: where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.  And we find bad teachers another line of work. And we have to be able to give parents the same choice
column5: frankly
column6: that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice. Charter schools aren't the only answer
column7: but they're providing competition. They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.  Now
column8: throwing money at the problem is not the answer. You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.  So I believe that we need to reward these good teachers.

column1: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people
column2: after having served in the military
column3: can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states. Look
column4: we must improve education in this country. As far as college education is concerned
column5: we need to make those student loans available. We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet. We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition. And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.

column2: we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well. But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do. Now we tried to do this under President Bush. He put forward No Child Left Behind. Unfortunately
column3: they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind. And local school districts end up having more of a burden
column4: a bunch of unfunded mandates
column5: the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs
column6: but we never followed through on the promise of funding
column7: and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.  So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education
column8: providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support. Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.  Charter schools
column9: I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions. I think it's important to foster competition inside the public schools.  And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves
column10: if they can't hack it
column11: then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.  Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system. And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.  Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was
column12: well
column13: you know
column14: we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.  I don't think America's youth are interest groups
column15: I think they're our future. And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize. We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.  And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned
column16: like lowering loan rates or what have you
column17: somebody has got to pay for it. It's not going to happen on its own.

column2: sure. I'm sure you're aware
column3: Senator Obama
column4: of the program in the Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number
column7: I think it's a thousand and some and some 9
column8: 000 parents asked to be eligible for that. Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had. And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.  And we all know the state of the Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: school system. That was vouchers. That was vouchers
column11: Senator Obama. And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.  Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned
column12: it was a great first beginning in my view. It had its flaws
column13: it had its problems
column14: the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective. And we need to fix a lot of the problems. We need to sit down and reauthorize it.  But
column16: spending more money isn't always the answer. I think the Head Start program is a great program. A lot of people
column17: including me
column18: said
column19: look
column20: it's not doing what it should do. By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.  Let's reform it. Let's reform it and fund it. That was
column22: out-of-bounds by the Democrats. We need to reform these programs. We need to have transparency. We need to have rewards. It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.  And I just said to you earlier
column23: town hall meeting after town hall meeting
column25: children -- precious children who have autism. Sarah Palin knows about that better than most. And we'll find and we'll spend the money
column26: research
column27: to find the cause of autism. And we'll care for these young children. And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.

column2: as you mentioned in our earlier comments
column3: that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform
column4: as well. And I will support those reforms
column5: and I will fund the ones that are reformed. But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem. And I've got to tell you that vouchers
column6: where they are requested and where they are agreed to
column7: are a good and workable system. And it's been proven.

column1: I'll just make a quick comment about vouchers in D.C. Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape
column2: and it has been for a very long time. And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
supports charters.
also.

column1: But the -- but here's the thing
column2: is that
column3: even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this
column4: because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2
column5: 000 slots. That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.  So if we are going to be serious about this issue
column6: we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on. And that's what I intend to do as president.

column1: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore
column2: we shouldn't do it
column3: even though it's working. I got it.
