column2: '15Oct'
column3: 5)	" I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court. That's not appropriate to do.

column1: I thought it was a bad decision. I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad. I think that decisions should rest in the hands of the states. I'm a federalist. And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test. Now
column2: let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up. Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion. We got together seven Republicans
column3: seven Democrats. You were offered a chance to join. You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of
column4: quote
column5: ""conservative judges.""  I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg. Not because I agreed with their ideology
column6: but because I thought they were qualified and that elections have consequences when presidents are nominated. This is a very important issue we're talking about.  Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees. Elections have consequences. They should be judged on their qualifications. And so that's what I will do.  I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution. And not legislating from the bench.

column1: I would consider anyone in their qualifications. I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications. But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.

column2: I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people. And it is true that this is going to be
column3: I think
column4: one of the most consequential decisions of the next president. It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.  Now I would not provide a litmus test. But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided. I think that abortion is a very difficult issue and it is a moral issue and one that I think good people on both sides can disagree on.  But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families
column5: their doctors
column6: their religious advisers
column7: are in the best position to make this decision. And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum
column8: any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum
column9: any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.

column1: So this is going to be an important issue. I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record
column2: who have the intellect
column3: and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through. I'll just give you one quick example. Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.  For years
column4: she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job. And when she brought a suit
column5: saying equal pay for equal work
column6: the judges said
column7: well
column8: you know
column9: it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit
column10: even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.  We tried to overturn it in the Senate. I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.  I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family
column11: trying to support her family
column12: and is being treated unfairly
column13: then the court has to stand up
column14: if nobody else will. And that's the kind of judge that I want.

column2: that law waived the statute of limitations
column3: which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years. It was a trial lawyer's dream. Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue. We have to change the culture of America. Those of us who are proudly pro-life understand that. And it's got to be courage and compassion that we show to a young woman who's facing this terribly difficult decision.  Senator Obama
column4: as a member of the Illinois State Senate
column5: voted in the Judiciary Committee against a law that would provide immediate medical attention to a child born of a failed abortion. He voted against that.  And then
column6: on the floor of the State Senate
column7: as he did 130 times as a state senator
column8: he voted present.  Then there was another bill before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the state of Illinois not that long ago
column9: where he voted against a ban on partial-birth abortion
column10: one of the late-term abortion
column11: a really -- one of the bad procedures
column12: a terrible. And then
column13: on the floor of the Illinois State Senate
column14: he voted present.  I don't know how you vote ""present"" on some of that. I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America. And that's his record
column15: and that's a matter of his record.  And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade
column16: about the Illinois State Senate. It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted
column17: I think
column18: in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.

column2: let me respond to this. If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant
column3: that's because it's not true. The -- here are the facts. There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade. The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment
column4: which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.  And the Illinois Medical Society
column5: the organization of doctors in Illinois
column6: voted against it. Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care
column7: and there was already a law in the books.  With respect to partial-birth abortion
column8: I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions
column9: partial-birth or otherwise
column10: as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life
column11: and this did not contain that exception.  And I attempted
column12: as many have in the past
column13: of including that so that it is constitutional. And that was rejected
column14: and that's why I voted present
column15: because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.  The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion. This is an issue that -- look
column16: it divides us. And in some ways
column17: it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.  But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say
column18: ""We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth
column19: communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity
column20: and providing options for adoption
column21: and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby.""  Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year
column22: and I think that's where we can find some common ground
column23: because nobody's pro-abortion. I think it's always a tragic situation.

column1: We should try to reduce these circumstances.

column2: the example of the eloquence of Senator Obama. He's health for the mother. You know
column3: that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything. That's the extreme pro-abortion position
column4: quote
column5: ""health."" But
column6: look
column7: Cindy and I are adoptive parents. We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives. We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.  But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn. Of course
column8: we have to come together. Of course
column9: we have to work together
column10: and
column11: of course
column12: it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision
column13: with a compassion
column14: that we'll help them with the adoptive services
column15: with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.

column1: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication
column2: because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power. So we've got to get our education system right. Now
column3: typically
column4: what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform
column5: and I think we need both. In some cases
column6: we are going to have to invest. Early childhood education
column7: which closes the achievement gap
column8: so that every child is prepared for school
column9: every dollar we invest in that
column10: we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores
column11: reduced dropout rates
column12: reduced delinquency rates.  I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers
column13: an army of new teachers
column14: especially in math and science
column16: give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.  And I think it's important for us to make college affordable. Right now
column17: I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college
column18: they are taking on $20
column25: 000 worth of debt
column26: and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields
column27: like basic research in science
column28: for example
column29: thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.  And that's why I've proposed a $4
column32: every year
column33: in exchange for some form of community service
column34: whether it's military service
column36: whether it's working in a community.  If we do those things
column37: then I believe that we can create a better school system.  But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention
column38: and that's parents. We can't do it just in the schools. Parents are going to have to show more responsibility. They've got to turn off the TV set
column39: put away the video games
column41: finally
column42: start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.

column2: it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century. There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle. But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?  So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places
column3: where we have charter schools
column4: where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.  And we find bad teachers another line of work. And we have to be able to give parents the same choice
column5: frankly
column6: that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice. Charter schools aren't the only answer
column7: but they're providing competition. They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.  Now
column8: throwing money at the problem is not the answer. You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.  So I believe that we need to reward these good teachers.

column1: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people
column2: after having served in the military
column3: can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states. Look
column4: we must improve education in this country. As far as college education is concerned
column5: we need to make those student loans available. We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet. We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition. And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.

column2: we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well. But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do. Now we tried to do this under President Bush. He put forward No Child Left Behind. Unfortunately
column3: they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind. And local school districts end up having more of a burden
column4: a bunch of unfunded mandates
column5: the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs
column6: but we never followed through on the promise of funding
column7: and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.  So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education
column8: providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support. Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.  Charter schools
column9: I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions. I think it's important to foster competition inside the public schools.  And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves
column10: if they can't hack it
column11: then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.  Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system. And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.  Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was
column12: well
column13: you know
column14: we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.  I don't think America's youth are interest groups
column15: I think they're our future. And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize. We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.  And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned
column16: like lowering loan rates or what have you
column17: somebody has got to pay for it. It's not going to happen on its own.

column2: sure. I'm sure you're aware
column3: Senator Obama
column4: of the program in the Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number
column7: I think it's a thousand and some and some 9
column8: 000 parents asked to be eligible for that. Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had. And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.  And we all know the state of the Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: school system. That was vouchers. That was vouchers
column11: Senator Obama. And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.  Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned
column12: it was a great first beginning in my view. It had its flaws
column13: it had its problems
column14: the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective. And we need to fix a lot of the problems. We need to sit down and reauthorize it.  But
column16: spending more money isn't always the answer. I think the Head Start program is a great program. A lot of people
column17: including me
column18: said
column19: look
column20: it's not doing what it should do. By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.  Let's reform it. Let's reform it and fund it. That was
column22: out-of-bounds by the Democrats. We need to reform these programs. We need to have transparency. We need to have rewards. It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.  And I just said to you earlier
column23: town hall meeting after town hall meeting
column25: children -- precious children who have autism. Sarah Palin knows about that better than most. And we'll find and we'll spend the money
column26: research
column27: to find the cause of autism. And we'll care for these young children. And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.

column2: as you mentioned in our earlier comments
column3: that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform
column4: as well. And I will support those reforms
column5: and I will fund the ones that are reformed. But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem. And I've got to tell you that vouchers
column6: where they are requested and where they are agreed to
column7: are a good and workable system. And it's been proven.

column1: I'll just make a quick comment about vouchers in D.C. Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape
column2: and it has been for a very long time. And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
supports charters.
also.

column1: But the -- but here's the thing
column2: is that
column3: even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this
column4: because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2
column5: 000 slots. That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.  So if we are going to be serious about this issue
column6: we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on. And that's what I intend to do as president.

column1: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore
column2: we shouldn't do it
column3: even though it's working. I got it.

column3: 5)	" I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court. That's not appropriate to do.

column1: I thought it was a bad decision. I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad. I think that decisions should rest in the hands of the states. I'm a federalist. And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test. Now
column2: let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up. Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion. We got together seven Republicans
column3: seven Democrats. You were offered a chance to join. You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of
column4: quote
column5: ""conservative judges.""  I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg. Not because I agreed with their ideology
column6: but because I thought they were qualified and that elections have consequences when presidents are nominated. This is a very important issue we're talking about.  Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees. Elections have consequences. They should be judged on their qualifications. And so that's what I will do.  I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution. And not legislating from the bench.

column1: I would consider anyone in their qualifications. I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications. But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.

column2: I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people. And it is true that this is going to be
column3: I think
column4: one of the most consequential decisions of the next president. It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.  Now I would not provide a litmus test. But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided. I think that abortion is a very difficult issue and it is a moral issue and one that I think good people on both sides can disagree on.  But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families
column5: their doctors
column6: their religious advisers
column7: are in the best position to make this decision. And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum
column8: any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum
column9: any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.

column1: So this is going to be an important issue. I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record
column2: who have the intellect
column3: and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through. I'll just give you one quick example. Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.  For years
column4: she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job. And when she brought a suit
column5: saying equal pay for equal work
column6: the judges said
column7: well
column8: you know
column9: it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit
column10: even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.  We tried to overturn it in the Senate. I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.  I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family
column11: trying to support her family
column12: and is being treated unfairly
column13: then the court has to stand up
column14: if nobody else will. And that's the kind of judge that I want.

column2: that law waived the statute of limitations
column3: which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years. It was a trial lawyer's dream. Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue. We have to change the culture of America. Those of us who are proudly pro-life understand that. And it's got to be courage and compassion that we show to a young woman who's facing this terribly difficult decision.  Senator Obama
column4: as a member of the Illinois State Senate
column5: voted in the Judiciary Committee against a law that would provide immediate medical attention to a child born of a failed abortion. He voted against that.  And then
column6: on the floor of the State Senate
column7: as he did 130 times as a state senator
column8: he voted present.  Then there was another bill before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the state of Illinois not that long ago
column9: where he voted against a ban on partial-birth abortion
column10: one of the late-term abortion
column11: a really -- one of the bad procedures
column12: a terrible. And then
column13: on the floor of the Illinois State Senate
column14: he voted present.  I don't know how you vote ""present"" on some of that. I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America. And that's his record
column15: and that's a matter of his record.  And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade
column16: about the Illinois State Senate. It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted
column17: I think
column18: in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.

column2: let me respond to this. If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant
column3: that's because it's not true. The -- here are the facts. There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade. The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment
column4: which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.  And the Illinois Medical Society
column5: the organization of doctors in Illinois
column6: voted against it. Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care
column7: and there was already a law in the books.  With respect to partial-birth abortion
column8: I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions
column9: partial-birth or otherwise
column10: as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life
column11: and this did not contain that exception.  And I attempted
column12: as many have in the past
column13: of including that so that it is constitutional. And that was rejected
column14: and that's why I voted present
column15: because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.  The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion. This is an issue that -- look
column16: it divides us. And in some ways
column17: it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.  But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say
column18: ""We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth
column19: communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity
column20: and providing options for adoption
column21: and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby.""  Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year
column22: and I think that's where we can find some common ground
column23: because nobody's pro-abortion. I think it's always a tragic situation.

column1: We should try to reduce these circumstances.

column2: the example of the eloquence of Senator Obama. He's health for the mother. You know
column3: that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything. That's the extreme pro-abortion position
column4: quote
column5: ""health."" But
column6: look
column7: Cindy and I are adoptive parents. We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives. We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.  But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn. Of course
column8: we have to come together. Of course
column9: we have to work together
column10: and
column11: of course
column12: it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision
column13: with a compassion
column14: that we'll help them with the adoptive services
column15: with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.

column1: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication
column2: because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power. So we've got to get our education system right. Now
column3: typically
column4: what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform
column5: and I think we need both. In some cases
column6: we are going to have to invest. Early childhood education
column7: which closes the achievement gap
column8: so that every child is prepared for school
column9: every dollar we invest in that
column10: we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores
column11: reduced dropout rates
column12: reduced delinquency rates.  I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers
column13: an army of new teachers
column14: especially in math and science
column16: give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.  And I think it's important for us to make college affordable. Right now
column17: I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college
column18: they are taking on $20
column25: 000 worth of debt
column26: and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields
column27: like basic research in science
column28: for example
column29: thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.  And that's why I've proposed a $4
column32: every year
column33: in exchange for some form of community service
column34: whether it's military service
column36: whether it's working in a community.  If we do those things
column37: then I believe that we can create a better school system.  But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention
column38: and that's parents. We can't do it just in the schools. Parents are going to have to show more responsibility. They've got to turn off the TV set
column39: put away the video games
column41: finally
column42: start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.

column2: it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century. There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle. But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?  So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places
column3: where we have charter schools
column4: where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.  And we find bad teachers another line of work. And we have to be able to give parents the same choice
column5: frankly
column6: that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice. Charter schools aren't the only answer
column7: but they're providing competition. They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.  Now
column8: throwing money at the problem is not the answer. You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.  So I believe that we need to reward these good teachers.

column1: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people
column2: after having served in the military
column3: can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states. Look
column4: we must improve education in this country. As far as college education is concerned
column5: we need to make those student loans available. We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet. We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition. And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.

column2: we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well. But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do. Now we tried to do this under President Bush. He put forward No Child Left Behind. Unfortunately
column3: they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind. And local school districts end up having more of a burden
column4: a bunch of unfunded mandates
column5: the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs
column6: but we never followed through on the promise of funding
column7: and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.  So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education
column8: providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support. Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.  Charter schools
column9: I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions. I think it's important to foster competition inside the public schools.  And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves
column10: if they can't hack it
column11: then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.  Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system. And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.  Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was
column12: well
column13: you know
column14: we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.  I don't think America's youth are interest groups
column15: I think they're our future. And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize. We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.  And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned
column16: like lowering loan rates or what have you
column17: somebody has got to pay for it. It's not going to happen on its own.

column2: sure. I'm sure you're aware
column3: Senator Obama
column4: of the program in the Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number
column7: I think it's a thousand and some and some 9
column8: 000 parents asked to be eligible for that. Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had. And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.  And we all know the state of the Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: school system. That was vouchers. That was vouchers
column11: Senator Obama. And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.  Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned
column12: it was a great first beginning in my view. It had its flaws
column13: it had its problems
column14: the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective. And we need to fix a lot of the problems. We need to sit down and reauthorize it.  But
column16: spending more money isn't always the answer. I think the Head Start program is a great program. A lot of people
column17: including me
column18: said
column19: look
column20: it's not doing what it should do. By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.  Let's reform it. Let's reform it and fund it. That was
column22: out-of-bounds by the Democrats. We need to reform these programs. We need to have transparency. We need to have rewards. It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.  And I just said to you earlier
column23: town hall meeting after town hall meeting
column25: children -- precious children who have autism. Sarah Palin knows about that better than most. And we'll find and we'll spend the money
column26: research
column27: to find the cause of autism. And we'll care for these young children. And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.

column2: as you mentioned in our earlier comments
column3: that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform
column4: as well. And I will support those reforms
column5: and I will fund the ones that are reformed. But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem. And I've got to tell you that vouchers
column6: where they are requested and where they are agreed to
column7: are a good and workable system. And it's been proven.

column1: I'll just make a quick comment about vouchers in D.C. Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape
column2: and it has been for a very long time. And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
supports charters.
also.

column1: But the -- but here's the thing
column2: is that
column3: even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this
column4: because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2
column5: 000 slots. That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.  So if we are going to be serious about this issue
column6: we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on. And that's what I intend to do as president.

column1: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore
column2: we shouldn't do it
column3: even though it's working. I got it.

column1: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape, and it has been for a very long time. column3: 5)	" I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court. That's not appropriate to do.

column1: I thought it was a bad decision. I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad. I think that decisions should rest in the hands of the states. I'm a federalist. And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test. Now
column2: let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up. Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion. We got together seven Republicans
column3: seven Democrats. You were offered a chance to join. You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of
column4: quote
column5: ""conservative judges.""  I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg. Not because I agreed with their ideology
column6: but because I thought they were qualified and that elections have consequences when presidents are nominated. This is a very important issue we're talking about.  Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees. Elections have consequences. They should be judged on their qualifications. And so that's what I will do.  I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution. And not legislating from the bench.

column1: I would consider anyone in their qualifications. I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications. But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.

column2: I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people. And it is true that this is going to be
column3: I think
column4: one of the most consequential decisions of the next president. It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.  Now I would not provide a litmus test. But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided. I think that abortion is a very difficult issue and it is a moral issue and one that I think good people on both sides can disagree on.  But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families
column5: their doctors
column6: their religious advisers
column7: are in the best position to make this decision. And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum
column8: any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum
column9: any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.

column1: So this is going to be an important issue. I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record
column2: who have the intellect
column3: and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through. I'll just give you one quick example. Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.  For years
column4: she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job. And when she brought a suit
column5: saying equal pay for equal work
column6: the judges said
column7: well
column8: you know
column9: it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit
column10: even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.  We tried to overturn it in the Senate. I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.  I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family
column11: trying to support her family
column12: and is being treated unfairly
column13: then the court has to stand up
column14: if nobody else will. And that's the kind of judge that I want.

column2: that law waived the statute of limitations
column3: which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years. It was a trial lawyer's dream. Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue. We have to change the culture of America. Those of us who are proudly pro-life understand that. And it's got to be courage and compassion that we show to a young woman who's facing this terribly difficult decision.  Senator Obama
column4: as a member of the Illinois State Senate
column5: voted in the Judiciary Committee against a law that would provide immediate medical attention to a child born of a failed abortion. He voted against that.  And then
column6: on the floor of the State Senate
column7: as he did 130 times as a state senator
column8: he voted present.  Then there was another bill before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the state of Illinois not that long ago
column9: where he voted against a ban on partial-birth abortion
column10: one of the late-term abortion
column11: a really -- one of the bad procedures
column12: a terrible. And then
column13: on the floor of the Illinois State Senate
column14: he voted present.  I don't know how you vote ""present"" on some of that. I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America. And that's his record
column15: and that's a matter of his record.  And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade
column16: about the Illinois State Senate. It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted
column17: I think
column18: in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.

column2: let me respond to this. If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant
column3: that's because it's not true. The -- here are the facts. There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade. The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment
column4: which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.  And the Illinois Medical Society
column5: the organization of doctors in Illinois
column6: voted against it. Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care
column7: and there was already a law in the books.  With respect to partial-birth abortion
column8: I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions
column9: partial-birth or otherwise
column10: as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life
column11: and this did not contain that exception.  And I attempted
column12: as many have in the past
column13: of including that so that it is constitutional. And that was rejected
column14: and that's why I voted present
column15: because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.  The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion. This is an issue that -- look
column16: it divides us. And in some ways
column17: it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.  But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say
column18: ""We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth
column19: communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity
column20: and providing options for adoption
column21: and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby.""  Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year
column22: and I think that's where we can find some common ground
column23: because nobody's pro-abortion. I think it's always a tragic situation.

column1: We should try to reduce these circumstances.

column2: the example of the eloquence of Senator Obama. He's health for the mother. You know
column3: that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything. That's the extreme pro-abortion position
column4: quote
column5: ""health."" But
column6: look
column7: Cindy and I are adoptive parents. We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives. We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.  But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn. Of course
column8: we have to come together. Of course
column9: we have to work together
column10: and
column11: of course
column12: it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision
column13: with a compassion
column14: that we'll help them with the adoptive services
column15: with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.

column1: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication
column2: because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power. So we've got to get our education system right. Now
column3: typically
column4: what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform
column5: and I think we need both. In some cases
column6: we are going to have to invest. Early childhood education
column7: which closes the achievement gap
column8: so that every child is prepared for school
column9: every dollar we invest in that
column10: we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores
column11: reduced dropout rates
column12: reduced delinquency rates.  I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers
column13: an army of new teachers
column14: especially in math and science
column16: give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.  And I think it's important for us to make college affordable. Right now
column17: I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college
column18: they are taking on $20
column25: 000 worth of debt
column26: and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields
column27: like basic research in science
column28: for example
column29: thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.  And that's why I've proposed a $4
column32: every year
column33: in exchange for some form of community service
column34: whether it's military service
column36: whether it's working in a community.  If we do those things
column37: then I believe that we can create a better school system.  But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention
column38: and that's parents. We can't do it just in the schools. Parents are going to have to show more responsibility. They've got to turn off the TV set
column39: put away the video games
column41: finally
column42: start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.

column2: it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century. There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle. But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?  So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places
column3: where we have charter schools
column4: where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.  And we find bad teachers another line of work. And we have to be able to give parents the same choice
column5: frankly
column6: that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice. Charter schools aren't the only answer
column7: but they're providing competition. They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.  Now
column8: throwing money at the problem is not the answer. You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.  So I believe that we need to reward these good teachers.

column1: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people
column2: after having served in the military
column3: can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states. Look
column4: we must improve education in this country. As far as college education is concerned
column5: we need to make those student loans available. We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet. We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition. And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.

column2: we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well. But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do. Now we tried to do this under President Bush. He put forward No Child Left Behind. Unfortunately
column3: they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind. And local school districts end up having more of a burden
column4: a bunch of unfunded mandates
column5: the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs
column6: but we never followed through on the promise of funding
column7: and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.  So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education
column8: providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support. Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.  Charter schools
column9: I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions. I think it's important to foster competition inside the public schools.  And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves
column10: if they can't hack it
column11: then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.  Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system. And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.  Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was
column12: well
column13: you know
column14: we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.  I don't think America's youth are interest groups
column15: I think they're our future. And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize. We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.  And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned
column16: like lowering loan rates or what have you
column17: somebody has got to pay for it. It's not going to happen on its own.

column2: sure. I'm sure you're aware
column3: Senator Obama
column4: of the program in the Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number
column7: I think it's a thousand and some and some 9
column8: 000 parents asked to be eligible for that. Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had. And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.  And we all know the state of the Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: school system. That was vouchers. That was vouchers
column11: Senator Obama. And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.  Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned
column12: it was a great first beginning in my view. It had its flaws
column13: it had its problems
column14: the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective. And we need to fix a lot of the problems. We need to sit down and reauthorize it.  But
column16: spending more money isn't always the answer. I think the Head Start program is a great program. A lot of people
column17: including me
column18: said
column19: look
column20: it's not doing what it should do. By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.  Let's reform it. Let's reform it and fund it. That was
column22: out-of-bounds by the Democrats. We need to reform these programs. We need to have transparency. We need to have rewards. It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.  And I just said to you earlier
column23: town hall meeting after town hall meeting
column25: children -- precious children who have autism. Sarah Palin knows about that better than most. And we'll find and we'll spend the money
column26: research
column27: to find the cause of autism. And we'll care for these young children. And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.

column2: as you mentioned in our earlier comments
column3: that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform
column4: as well. And I will support those reforms
column5: and I will fund the ones that are reformed. But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem. And I've got to tell you that vouchers
column6: where they are requested and where they are agreed to
column7: are a good and workable system. And it's been proven.

column1: I'll just make a quick comment about vouchers in D.C. Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape
column2: and it has been for a very long time. And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
supports charters.
also.

column1: But the -- but here's the thing
column2: is that
column3: even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this
column4: because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2
column5: 000 slots. That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.  So if we are going to be serious about this issue
column6: we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on. And that's what I intend to do as president.

column1: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore
column2: we shouldn't do it
column3: even though it's working. I got it.

column3: 5)	" I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court. That's not appropriate to do.

column1: I thought it was a bad decision. I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad. I think that decisions should rest in the hands of the states. I'm a federalist. And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test. Now
column2: let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up. Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion. We got together seven Republicans
column3: seven Democrats. You were offered a chance to join. You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of
column4: quote
column5: ""conservative judges.""  I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg. Not because I agreed with their ideology
column6: but because I thought they were qualified and that elections have consequences when presidents are nominated. This is a very important issue we're talking about.  Senator Obama voted against Justice Breyer and Justice Roberts on the grounds that they didn't meet his ideological standards. That's not the way we should judge these nominees. Elections have consequences. They should be judged on their qualifications. And so that's what I will do.  I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution. And not legislating from the bench.

column1: I would consider anyone in their qualifications. I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications. But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.

column2: I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people. And it is true that this is going to be
column3: I think
column4: one of the most consequential decisions of the next president. It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.  Now I would not provide a litmus test. But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided. I think that abortion is a very difficult issue and it is a moral issue and one that I think good people on both sides can disagree on.  But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families
column5: their doctors
column6: their religious advisers
column7: are in the best position to make this decision. And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum
column8: any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum
column9: any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.

column1: So this is going to be an important issue. I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record
column2: who have the intellect
column3: and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through. I'll just give you one quick example. Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.  For years
column4: she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job. And when she brought a suit
column5: saying equal pay for equal work
column6: the judges said
column7: well
column8: you know
column9: it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit
column10: even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.  We tried to overturn it in the Senate. I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.  I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family
column11: trying to support her family
column12: and is being treated unfairly
column13: then the court has to stand up
column14: if nobody else will. And that's the kind of judge that I want.

column3: which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years. It was a trial lawyer's dream. Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue. We have to change the culture of America. Those of us who are proudly pro-life understand that. And it's got to be courage and compassion that we show to a young woman who's facing this terribly difficult decision.  Senator Obama
column4: as a member of the Illinois State Senate
column5: voted in the Judiciary Committee against a law that would provide immediate medical attention to a child born of a failed abortion. He voted against that.  And then
column6: on the floor of the State Senate
column7: as he did 130 times as a state senator
column8: he voted present.  Then there was another bill before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the state of Illinois not that long ago
column9: where he voted against a ban on partial-birth abortion
column10: one of the late-term abortion
column11: a really -- one of the bad procedures
column12: a terrible. And then
column13: on the floor of the Illinois State Senate
column14: he voted present.  I don't know how you vote ""present"" on some of that. I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America. And that's his record
column15: and that's a matter of his record.  And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade
column16: about the Illinois State Senate. It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted
column17: I think
column18: in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.

column2: let me respond to this. If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant
column3: that's because it's not true. The -- here are the facts. There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade. The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment
column4: which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.  And the Illinois Medical Society
column5: the organization of doctors in Illinois
column6: voted against it. Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care
column7: and there was already a law in the books.  With respect to partial-birth abortion
column8: I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions
column9: partial-birth or otherwise
column10: as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life
column11: and this did not contain that exception.  And I attempted
column12: as many have in the past
column13: of including that so that it is constitutional. And that was rejected
column14: and that's why I voted present
column15: because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.  The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion. This is an issue that -- look
column16: it divides us. And in some ways
column17: it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.  But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say
column18: ""We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth
column19: communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity
column20: and providing options for adoption
column21: and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby.""  Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year
column22: and I think that's where we can find some common ground
column23: because nobody's pro-abortion. I think it's always a tragic situation.

column1: We should try to reduce these circumstances.

column2: the example of the eloquence of Senator Obama. He's health for the mother. You know
column3: that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything. That's the extreme pro-abortion position
column4: quote
column5: ""health."" But
column6: look
column7: Cindy and I are adoptive parents. We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives. We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.  But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn. Of course
column8: we have to come together. Of course
column9: we have to work together
column10: and
column11: of course
column12: it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision
column13: with a compassion
column14: that we'll help them with the adoptive services
column15: with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.

column1: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication
column2: because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power. So we've got to get our education system right. Now
column3: typically
column4: what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform
column5: and I think we need both. In some cases
column6: we are going to have to invest. Early childhood education
column7: which closes the achievement gap
column8: so that every child is prepared for school
column9: every dollar we invest in that
column10: we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores
column11: reduced dropout rates
column12: reduced delinquency rates.  I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers
column13: an army of new teachers
column14: especially in math and science
column16: give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.  And I think it's important for us to make college affordable. Right now
column17: I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college
column18: they are taking on $20
column25: 000 worth of debt
column26: and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields
column27: like basic research in science
column28: for example
column29: thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.  And that's why I've proposed a $4
column32: every year
column33: in exchange for some form of community service
column34: whether it's military service
column36: whether it's working in a community.  If we do those things
column37: then I believe that we can create a better school system.  But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention
column38: and that's parents. We can't do it just in the schools. Parents are going to have to show more responsibility. They've got to turn off the TV set
column39: put away the video games
column41: finally
column42: start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.

column2: it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century. There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle. But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?  So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places
column3: where we have charter schools
column4: where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.  And we find bad teachers another line of work. And we have to be able to give parents the same choice
column5: frankly
column6: that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice. Charter schools aren't the only answer
column7: but they're providing competition. They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.  Now
column8: throwing money at the problem is not the answer. You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.  So I believe that we need to reward these good teachers.

column1: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people
column2: after having served in the military
column3: can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states. Look
column4: we must improve education in this country. As far as college education is concerned
column5: we need to make those student loans available. We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet. We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition. And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.

column2: we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well. But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do. Now we tried to do this under President Bush. He put forward No Child Left Behind. Unfortunately
column3: they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind. And local school districts end up having more of a burden
column4: a bunch of unfunded mandates
column5: the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs
column6: but we never followed through on the promise of funding
column7: and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.  So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education
column8: providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support. Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.  Charter schools
column9: I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions. I think it's important to foster competition inside the public schools.  And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves
column10: if they can't hack it
column11: then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.  Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system. And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.  Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was
column12: well
column13: you know
column14: we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.  I don't think America's youth are interest groups
column15: I think they're our future. And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize. We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.  And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned
column16: like lowering loan rates or what have you
column17: somebody has got to pay for it. It's not going to happen on its own.

column2: sure. I'm sure you're aware
column3: Senator Obama
column4: of the program in the Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number
column7: I think it's a thousand and some and some 9
column8: 000 parents asked to be eligible for that. Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had. And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.  And we all know the state of the Washington
column9: D.C.
column10: school system. That was vouchers. That was vouchers
column11: Senator Obama. And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.  Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned
column12: it was a great first beginning in my view. It had its flaws
column13: it had its problems
column14: the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective. And we need to fix a lot of the problems. We need to sit down and reauthorize it.  But
column16: spending more money isn't always the answer. I think the Head Start program is a great program. A lot of people
column17: including me
column18: said
column19: look
column20: it's not doing what it should do. By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.  Let's reform it. Let's reform it and fund it. That was
column22: out-of-bounds by the Democrats. We need to reform these programs. We need to have transparency. We need to have rewards. It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.  And I just said to you earlier
column23: town hall meeting after town hall meeting
column25: children -- precious children who have autism. Sarah Palin knows about that better than most. And we'll find and we'll spend the money
column26: research
column27: to find the cause of autism. And we'll care for these young children. And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.

column2: as you mentioned in our earlier comments
column3: that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform
column4: as well. And I will support those reforms
column5: and I will fund the ones that are reformed. But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem. And I've got to tell you that vouchers
column6: where they are requested and where they are agreed to
column7: are a good and workable system. And it's been proven.

column1: I'll just make a quick comment about vouchers in D.C. Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape
column2: and it has been for a very long time. And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
supports charters.
also.

column1: But the -- but here's the thing
column2: is that
column3: even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this
column4: because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2
column5: 000 slots. That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.  So if we are going to be serious about this issue
column6: we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on. And that's what I intend to do as president.

column1: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore
column2: we shouldn't do it
column3: even though it's working. I got it.
